On 22 December 2016 at about 0050H, a Singapore registered harbour tug Resilient completed her assignment to assist in the berthing of a tanker vessel at Jurong Island Jetty (OVL2). The tug was operated by a Tug Master and an Engineer Officer.
As the tug’s next assignment, to assist in an un-berthing operation at Jurong Island Jetty 1 (OVL1), was in two hours’ time, the Tug Master decided to moor his tug at a mooring buoy at Banyan Basin, rather than going back to the tug operator’s West Coast Base (WCB) station, which would mean a 1.5-hour return trip to OVL1.
At about 0104H, the tug arrived at the Banyan Basin mooring location. The Engineer Officer (EO), who had been tasked to secure the tug to the buoy, fell into the sea while attempting to secure the tug to the buoy. Search and rescue operation was unsuccessful. Two days later, the body of the EO was found in Indonesian waters off Karimun Island, about 19 nautical miles southwest of the Banyan Basin.
The Transport Safety Investigation Bureau classified the occurrence as a very serious marine casualty.
The investigation reiterated the importance of wearing a floatation device/ life-vest while working on-board a vessel. Other factors contributed to the occurrence included the mooring of the tug at a non-designated location and the lack of risk assessment of potential hazards involved in mooring operation, particularly, involving a tug with two-man crew.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

At 0628 on 4 December 2016, the German-flagged container ship HANNI ran aground off Mühlenberger Loch in Hamburg while sailing for Bremerhaven. The master and chief officer were on the bridge. An overspeed protection alarm was issued for the main engine at 0621. The main engine then stopped automatically. At 0623, the FINJA (a tanker) approached from the opposite direction on the Elbe fairway and it was just possible to avoid a collision with her by setting the rudder to hard to starboard. After the failure of the main engine, the HANNI drifted to the other side of the fairway in an arc toward her port side and ran aground within seven minutes. The main engine was operational again only one minute earlier and both anchors ready to drop. There were no injuries and no pollutants escaped. The unsuccessful first salvage attempt involving two tugs began at 0700 with the tide already running out. The second salvage attempt at 1830 on the next high tide was successful.

On 3 December 2016, when the Mathu Bhum was enroute from Singapore to Yangon, Myanmar, the engine room crew were dismantling the Fire, Bilge and Ballast (FBB) pump with a view to taking some photographs of its condition for submission to the Class surveyor.    

The engine room crew assigned by the Second Engineer to work on the FBB pump comprised the Fourth Engineer (the engineer-in-charge), the Oiler, the Wireman and the Engine Cadet. Pre-job briefing and risk assessments were carried out before the start of the dismantling work.
 
By 1200H the crew managed to remove a number of bolts using appropriate spanners and wrenches. Some of the bolts however were badly seized and could not be removed. To remove the seized bolts, the crew decided to fabricate a tool by welding a metal wedge piece onto the seized bolt, in order to loosen the seized bolt by knocking on the welded metal piece with a hammer. Hot work permits were issued for the dismantling work.
  
At about 1400H, the Fourth Engineer while standing on the engine room tank top attempted to weld the wedge. He instructed the Engine Cadet to switch on the power for the welding machine which was located in the engine room workshop two decks above. At the engine room workshop the Engine Cadet noticed that the fitter was doing some other welding work and his welding cable was connected to the welding machine. Upon being informed by the Engine Cadet of the Fourth Engineer’s instruction, the fitter removed his welding cable and connected the Fourth Engineer’s welding cable to the welding machine. 

This resulted in the fatal electrocution of the Fourth Engineer.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 22 November 2016, at 1357 (LT), the Maltese registered bulk carrier Robusto ran aground and remained stranded in the entrance of El Dekheila Channel, Egypt in position 31 10.18 N 029 48.25 E. The vessel had completed her sea passage from Narvic, Norway, fully loaded with 163,000 metric tonnes of iron ore, with a draught of 17.5 m.
About 15 minutes prior to the grounding, two pilots had boarded the vessel and proceeded to the bridge where the master, third mate and a helmsman were already in the wheelhouse.
The vessel was proceeding towards the entrance of El Dekheila Channel, following course alternations recommended by the pilot. The pilot s orders were given directly to the helmsman. The safety investigation revealed that the course recommended by the pilot was different from the one prepared in the passage planning. Moreover, during the navigation of the Channel, the vessel was navigated close to shallow areas, leading to the vessel running aground and remaining stranded. Soundings and subsequent in-water inspections revealed no water ingress in any of the vessel s double bottom tanks. No injuries were reported.
Lightering operations commenced on 25 November 2016 and were completed on 27 November 2016 at 1435. Refloating operations were initiated after approximately 5,000 mt of cargo had been discharged from the vessel. The vessel refloated on 28 November and berthed safely at 1645.

Two Coastguard search and rescue helicopters have been sent to evacuate the crew after a cargo vessel collided with a stone barge three miles south west of Dover.

SOLASStatus: Meridian: Unknown/unspecified, MSC Diana: Unknown/unspecified, New Yorker: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 0153 on 20 November 2016, the large container vessels NEWYORKER and MSC DIANA were moored one behind the other at the container terminal in Bremerhaven. Without any discernible alteration in course or speed, the coaster MERIDIAN first sailed into the port side of the NEWYORKER, pushed along her toward the stern into the gap between the two container vessels, where she then rammed the pier with her bow. In the prevailing situation, it seems that the rising tide played a role in that it pushed the MERIDIAN against the MSC DIANA's bulbous bow with her starboard side. Shortly after, the MERIDIAN was able to manoeuvre clear again in a sternward direction. This contact with the bulbous bow left no visible damage on the MSC DIANA. However, it did result in indentation with cracking on the starboard side of the MERIDIAN. The MERIDIAN's crew was able to stop the slight water ingress that followed. The shell plating of the NEWYORKER was dented several times but no cracking was caused. The collision with the pier caused heavy damage to the MERIDIAN's fore section. The damage sustained by the pier's structure was so heavy that operation of the container gantry crane on top of it had to be suspended temporarily. There were neither physical injuries nor environmental pollution.

At approximately 1200 (UTC) on 12 November 2016, the owner of the 7.75m motor cruiser Vasquez fell unconscious after being overcome by carbon monoxide (CO) that had emitted from his boat’s inboard petrol engine. Although rescuers came to his aid and conducted cardio-pulmonary resuscitation, it was not possible to save his life. Two of the rescuers had to be treated for the effects of CO poisoning following the accident.
The CO was found to have originated from the rubber bellows of the wet-exhaust system of the engine, which was not only leaking gas but also water. The boat’s engine had not been regularly serviced, and evidence revealed that the exhaust system of the engine had been modified during the boat’s life.

Due to the collision, the small fishing boat sunk. Eight (8) fishermen were recovered from the water and one (1) fisherman was declared missing according to the fishermen declaration.The Marine Rescue Coordination Centre (MRCC) Cape Town (South Africa) and Cross Cap Gris-Nez (France) coordinated the Search and Rescue (SAR) operation. SAR started on the 9th November 2016, immediately after the collision and continued until 18:00 hrs LT on the 10th November 2016. Several vessels participated.The 9thfisherman was reported still missing after SAR operations ceased. The 7 rescued were declared as Democratic Republic of the Congo (RDC) citizens and 1 from Angola. Nobody held an ID nor a crew list existed. The missing fisherman was declared as RDC citizen by the other rescued fishermen. No I.D. or any other personal information was given. It was not possible to cross-check the information. Diving survey showed neither damage nor deformation on SURFER 3603 hull and waterjet.

Sustained main engine crankcase explosion, caught fire, lost power and drifted in the sea of Okhotsk 270 miles SW of Magadan in heavy swells.
The blaze was extinguished by the crew. One crew member was killed and two sustained injuries. The two injured crew were transferred to the Katayevo and brought to Magadan the following day for medical attention. Subsequently taken in tow by Arkadija and arrived at anchorage off Okhotsk on 10/11/16 for inspection and disembarkation of non-essential crew. Arrived in tow at Vladivostok on 28/11/16 for further inspections. Damaged beyond economical repair.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

InitialEvent: Occurrence with person - dead as a result of slipping and falling
SummaryOfEvents: The vessel was discharging cargo at Port of Burgas, Bulgaria. There were no witnesses to the accident, but the available evidence indicated that the docker probably fell from the cargo hold's ladder, while attempting to go down into the cargo hold. The docker died from his injuries later in the ambulance on the way to the hospital.

Location: Persian Gulf 34 miles SW of Khark Island
SummaryOfEvents: Took on water in the engine room and sank in the Persian Gulf 34 miles SW of Khark Island. Local SAR units despatched 2 ships and 3 tugs to attend the scene. Two dewatering pumps were delivered on board to assist in pumping out the water. All 12 crew were rescued by a passing passenger ship. Taken in tow in an attempt to reach land but was subsequently abandoned and left to sink. No pollution or injuries were reported.
Vessel fire resulting in the total constructive loss of the vessel.  No reported injuries.

Location: MAKASSAR STRAIT 17 MILES S OF PULAU BIRAH BIRAHAN, KALIMANTAN TIMUR
SummaryOfEvents: Developed list to port and sank whilst underway in the Makassar Strait 17 miles S of Pulau Birah Birahan, Kalimantan Timur in heavy weather. SAR teams attended the scene. Nine crew were safely rescued by nearby Peace Ark and were sent to the local hospital for medical attention. Local authorities effected a search for 2 missing crew.

SOLASStatus: DEWARUCI PERKASA: Unknown/unspecified, DOLPHIN NUSANTARA 2: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Sustained steering gear failure and in collision with Dolphin Nusantara and Daya Lestari' in Selat Madura off Gresik. The ship sustained a breach in the hull, took on water, developed a list and sank rapidly. No pollution was reported. Nine crew were rescued, 1 was found dead and 3 still missing. Local authorities effected search for missing crew using divers. The weather at the time of the incident was good but with strong currents.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: At Kobe-ku Hanshin port, Kobe city, Hyogo prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: During cargo handling work on the ship at Kobe-ku Hanshin Port, two stevedores died and one stevedore was injured.

On October 30, 2016 between 0140 LT and 0150 LT, position Lat 37-24.8 N Long 123-45.8 E, the vessel collided with Chinese Fishing vessel Jin Han Yu 04856, resulted to sink the fishing vessel with 6 fishermen missing in Yellow Sea. Master and crews onboard the vessel Menaro did not accept they had collided the fishing boat. China MSA detained the vessel. VDR, ECDIS and underwater survey found the evidence that vessel had indeed collided. The weather conditions recorded as, Wind- Northerly force 8, Sea- rough, Swell- rough and good visibility, congested with fishing vessels.

Location: Dry dock in Rubbestadneset, Southern Norway
SummaryOfEvents: Caught fire in passenger accommodation area whilst undergoing repairs in dry dock at Rubbestadneset. Five workers on board were evacuated safely. The blaze was brought under control by local fire services 8 hours later. 423 local residents were evacuated temporarily due to heavy smoke pollution. No injuries were reported. Inspection and investigation effected. Sustained extensive damage and beyond economical repair.

On the 26th of October 2016, at 13.50 Hours LT, the Tug-Boat Symphony 14 (under Singaporean flag) towing the HSC Mykonos Jet (under Cypriot flag), departed from Mokpo-South Korea. The general voyage plan was from Mokpo-South Korea via Singapore Straits and via Suez Canal to a shipyard in Greece for repairs. The HSC Mykonos Jet was provided with a certificate confirming its fitness to be towed. The fitness to tow survey included verification that the towing arrangement was in compliance with the approved tow plan and voyage plan. It also included an assessment of the suitability of the vessels involved towing equipment, passage planning, navigational equipment etc.On the 29th of October 2016, at about 00:35 Hours LT, the aft draft of the HSC Mykonos Jet increased and got trim by the stern. There was very strong tension on the main tow wire from the HSC Mykonos Jet and the Tug-Boat Symphony 14 started surging backwards.At 01:00 Hours LT, the Tug-Master ordered to pay out the main towing wire to reduce the tension on it. At 01:20 Hours LT, the Tug-Master ordered to let go the main tow wire completely to the end, to avoid imminent danger to the Tug-Boat.After the Tug-Boat released all the length of the towing wire, remained near the HSC Mykonos Jet. Subsequently reported that the HSC Mykonos Jet submerged about 3/4ths of its hull.The Managers of the HSC Mykonos Jet requested assistance under Lloyds Open Form (LOF) terms. The Salvage company Zhoushan Kamji Marine Agency Ltd organized the salvage operation on an urgent basis. The Tug-Boat Symphony 14 remained nearby HSC Mykonos Jet.At 01:30 Hours LT, the HSC Mykonos Jet sunk in position Lat. 29 50 96 N - Long 123 36 49 E, in the East China Sea (east sea area of Zhoushan city Zhejiang province of People's Republic of China).The weather conditions at the time of the incident were NE winds 30-32 knots / 7 Beaufort, Sea state 6, with swell 3-4 meters.The Master of the Tug-Boat Symphony 14 broadcasted Navigational Warning to all vessels in the vicinity and reported to the Coast Radio Stations in the area.Following the sinking of the HSC Mykonos Jet, the vessels Class was withdrawn on 29 October, 2016 for the reason of Constructive Total Loss (IACS code "1c").

Location: IN THE NORTH PACIFIC OCEAN 317 MILES E OF MIYAKO, IWATE
SummaryOfEvents: Caught fire following a collision with an unidentified cargo ship in the North Pacific Ocean 317 miles E of Miyako, Iwate. One crew member fell overboard and went missing. The remaining 52 crew were rescued by neighbouring fishing vessels. Sustained serious damage, was disabled and left drifting. Reported blaze was caused by short circuit in wiring. Japan coast guard despatched a helicopter and a patrol vessel to search for the missing crew member. Blaze was subsequently extinguished and taken in tow.

InitialEvent: crew member fell from twin deck to tanktop in no.1 cargo hold.
SummaryOfEvents: On 25 October 2016 at about 1345 hours, on board the Hong Kong registered general dry cargo ship SPRING SALIM during the transit from Kendari to Gresik at the position of 05-22.0S, 123-16.3E Banda Sea, Indonesia, the bosun fell from a height of about 6.2 metres at the No.1 panel of tween deck hatch cover into the bottom of No.1 cargo hold to his death.

While adjusting mooring lines (ship was berthed) a line got hung up on a winch drum and then fed onto storage drum.  An AB became hung up in the mooring line and drum and was seriously injured.  He received first aid on board and was then transferred to hospital, where he subsequently died.

M.V. Pacific Cebu, previous named as Medi Cebu, is a Panama registered, ocean going, geared, steel construction, single decker, bulk carrier, having 5 cargo holds/hatches and 4 deck cranes. Vessel can load maximum capacity – Grain-67756.3 cu.m / Bale-65600.5 cu.m. Vessel’s overall length is 189.99 m, moulded breadth is 32.26 m and moulded depth is 17.00 m. Main propulsion is Diesel engine of M.C.O. 7800 KW, 10600PS X 116 RPM, CSO 6630 KW, Single screw, Mitsui MAN B&W 6S50MC-Mark 6x1 set.   Official no. 34097-08-C, Call Sign 3EMB5, owned by Rigel Trading Corp./Marshall Island and Managed by First Lines Co. S.A./ Greece, Classification Society of vessel is Lloyd’s Register of Shipping having class notation 100A1 Bulk Carrier, Strengthened for Heavy Cargoes Holds no. 2 and 4 may be empty, ESP, ESN, LI LMC, UMS, built at Tsuneishi Heavy Industries (Cebu Philipines) Inc., keel laid on 12th April 2002 and delivered on 01st Oct 2002.
While the vessel was loading gypsum at Salalah, Oman, the accident took place at about 1055 hrs on 24th Oct 2016. At the time of accident M.V.Pacific Cebu had 20 crew including Master. The breakup of complement nationality wise is : 02 Helenic and 18 Filipino.
Vessel arrived at Salalah (Oman) on 24th Oct 2016, at 0400 hrs. vessel made fast, pilot away and Finished with engines. At 0700 hrs.  started to connect the grabs to cranes no. 1, 2 & 4 and at 0755 completed connection of grabs to cranes 1, 2 & 4.  At 0815 hrs. commenced loading in hold no. 5 and at 0822 hrs. started loading in holds no. 1 & 3. At 0810 hrs. Chief Officer and Bosun informed Masterthat the runner wire of no. 3 crane was damaged and required to be replaced. 
Bosun – Mr. Nikolaos Papanikolaou, in presence of Chief Officer – Mr. Marlon Bongcawil Panes, AB – Alberto Banzales, and AB – Raul Bongar, climbed up on no. 3 crane to clear the jammed new wire that was being replaced. While clearing it, he got a jerk and fell off the crane boom on  top of hatch no. 4. He was bleeding through his right ear, it was evident that he had head injury. After giving first aid on board he was shifted to shore hospital by ambulance. Within an hour he was declared dead due to internal bleeding.

Location: SOUTH CHINA SEA OFF GUANGDONG PROVINCE
SummaryOfEvents: Sustained engine failure in the South China Sea off Guangdong province. In-situ repair attempts by crew were unsuccessful and anchored in the Qiongzhou Strait off Hainan to await assistance. Subsequently taken in tow by tug and arriving in Hong Kong, China, for cargo discharge on 02/11/16 prior to proceeding to the Yiu Lian dockyard for inspection the following day. Later sold for recycling.

On 20 October 2016, the vessel was navigating the Caribbean Sea, en route to Coronel, Chile. The maintenance works on the crane grab, stowed on a platform above the main deck, had been completed late in the afternoon. The crew members descended down the fixed vertical ladder. The bosun, who at the time was standing on top of the grab, was the last one to descend, when he fell from a height of about six metres.

It was established that as he un-clipped his fall arrester to step down from the grab, he lost his footing and fell down on the platform and on the main deck.  He suffered severe head injuries. The crew members administered first aid on site and later in the ship’s hospital.  However, an hour later, he succumbed to his injuries.

MT Highsea Passage left Dickowita fishery harbor on 20th October 2016 at 1540 Hrs to port of Colombo. Due to the Inward / Outward movements of the harbor, vessel was advised to hold the position.Around 1625 Hrs, Master altered the course to 180 deg and engine was stopped. At 1645 hrs vessel ran aground at position 06 deg 59.2' N  079 deg 51.5' E. There were no injuries or pollution, but the vessel sustained minor damages.

InitialEvent: AB fell from the the crane platform and passed away.
SummaryOfEvents:
Toolbox Talk held on the bridge for crew members involved with greasing the wires on canes no. 1 and no. 3, permits to work aloft issued.
Crane no. 3 was completed.
Commenced preparing equipment to grease crane no. 2 wires.
AB was at the top of the crane no. 1 crane pedestal gantry where the jib from no. 2 crane rests, when he fell approximately 10-12m.
Coast Guard will called for medical assistance
AB pronounced deceased

Caught fire on vehicle deck no. 7 whilst moored at berth no. 340 at the port of Antwerp.
After several hours of fire-fighting the fire was reported to be under control but there were still some significant hot-spots. The volume of extinguishing water caused the vessel to develop a starboard list. All 24 crew were evacuated safely. No injuries and no pollution were reported. Firefighting tugs '22', '40', '80' and '81' and local fire services fought the fire which subsequently spread to decks nos. 8 and 9. The blaze was brought under control the following day. Sustained substantial damage to the interior and most vehicles carried as cargo on decks nos. 7, 8 and 9 were destroyed. Subsequently the blaze was extinguished on 22/10/16. Damaged beyond economical repair and towed to Aliaga, Turkey for recycling.

As reported from ship’s Master, M/V “SILVER SKY” arrived in the port of Ant-werp/Belgium on 13 October 2016 early AM LT hours after having completed her cargo operations in Hamburg/Germany at 14:30LT of 12 October 2016. At the time of arrival to Sallaum Terminal in Antwerp, the vessel along with vehicles was also loaded with 1089 Timber Bundles (approximately 1200 MT). According to Master’s statement, the vessel was berthed in Antwerp on her Starboard Side to the pier on 13 October 2016 at approximately 01:45 LT. “SILVER SKY”, according to her Minimum Safe Manning Certificate and the provided Crew List, was adequately manned with the rest hours of seafarers observed in good order. 
According to the Master of the ship, the vessel did not face any problems during her voyage from Hamburg to Antwerp and all the required procedures were followed.
On 14 October 2016, starting at 05:10 LT and finishing at 16:15 LT, the vessel dis-charged 1089 Timber Bundles and vehicles. On 19 October 2016, the ship continued her cargo operations, beginning at 14:00 LT and completing her day vehicles loading for the ports of Cotonou, Lagos, Pointe-Noire and Douala at 21:15 LT. Vessel’s draft was 7.80m in the fore and 8.10m in the aft parts, while the weather visibility was reported as good.
At approximately 23:45 of the same day with the weather conditions being good and with NW wind of about 2-3 Bf scale, the AB on duty reported to Third Officer that there was fire on deck. Third Officer proceeded to the Car Deck No. 5 and then to Car Deck No. 7 where he saw that flames were visible. He activated the Fire Alarm and called ship’s Master in order to inform him about what had happened.
The approximate position at which is possible that the fire started, is approximately be-tween Fr. 157 – 160 of Deck No. 7 in the area connecting Hold No. 1 to Hold No. 2.

Caught fire in the cargo hold whilst underway in the Laccadive Sea near Thilafushi.
Local firefighting team and Maldives national defence force attended the scene. 18 crew members were rescued safely with 1 crew missing. Search and rescue operations conducted by local emergency services. The remains of the missing crew member were discovered amongst the burnt debris 4 days later.

Location: off the east coast of Long Island in the Vitiaz Strait
SummaryOfEvents:
On 17 October 2015, M/V Foxhound departed Didi Pt., Papua New Guinea (PNG) for Zhangjiagang, China. While transiting towards Kimbe, PNG to obtain clearance from PNG Port Authorities, the ship encountered very rough seas from the south east. After continuous foundering on her starboard quarter aft moving abeam, the ship started to heel initially 15° to port. M/V Foxhound failed to recover her upright position. Due to the slanting of the ship and added weight from her over stowed cargo, the cargo lashing on deck no. 1 to collapse, causing several of the cargo logs to roll over from the cargo deck. The ship continued to list to 35° to port prompting more logs to roll and causing the forward port side post to collapse. 

The Master of M/V “Foxhound” ordered to stop engine and immediately sent a distress message to the ship’s agent in PNG, subsequently, he activated the ship’s radar transponders (SART/EPIRB).After one hour, the Master gave the order to Abandon Ship and the crew boarded the lifeboat located at the ship’s starboard side. After several hours, the crews were later rescued by M/V “Cosco Shanghai”

On 22 October 2015, M/V “Cosco Shanghai” arrived at Port Botany, Sydney, Australia with all Filipino crew. M/V Foxhound was later found to ran aground at the position LAT 05° 18.162” S LONG 147° 11.095”E off the east coast of Long Island in the Vitiaz Strait. There was no reported oil spill or fatalities involved in the incident. On 14 November 2015, the Office of the Administrator (OADM) received an electronic mail (email) from Captain Md. Nafizul Hossain, Acting Executive Manager, Marine Operation Division, National Maritime Safety Authority (NMSA) PNG, about the incident.

The NMSA-PNG, likewise, notified the owners and operators of M/V “Foxhound “that it will conduct an independent Preliminary Investigation pursuant to Section 165 and 166 of the Merchant Shipping Act (MSA) of 1975 in order to ascertain the causes and consequences resulting from the abandonment of the ship by its crew whilst on a passage from FONSEN Log Pond in West New Britain to Kimbe.

It was also stated in its letter-advisory that the ship will be under DETENTION until the completion of the Investigation and a certificate of seaworthiness has been issued by the vessel’s Classification Society (Nippon Kaiji Kyokai) to its satisfaction.

Garip Baba was enroute to Rotterdam, The Netherlands from Hopa, Turkey with 5,500 metric tonnes of corn in bulk.  The vessel was navigating smoothly and there was only very gentle rolling.
While underway, the crew members took the opportunity to carry out planned routine maintenance tasks, which they would otherwise have limited time to carry out in port, if any. The freefall lifeboat launching system required monthly greasing in accordance with the manufacturer s instructions.It was hence decided to task the bosun to carry out the necessary greasing.One AB was to accompany him throughout the duration of the job.
The bosun was very experienced and found no problem to climb the freefall lifeboat davits and work around it. The safety harness hook was attached to the lifeboat railing. At one point in time, the bosun moved to relocate himself to a different position on the davits. During this process, he lost his balance and fell down from the davits to the poop deck, in close proximity of the mooring winches.
Considering the height of the fall, the bosun was disembarked and transferred to a hospital in Italy for further medical assistance and necessary treatment. The bosun was diagnosed with back injuries and had to undergo a surgical intervention before he was actually repatriated.

Location: Chindwin River, about 72 kilometres north of the city of Monywa
SummaryOfEvents: On Saturday morning 15 October 2016, an unknown passenger ferry carrying at least 250 people sank in the Chindwin River, about 72 kilometres North of the city of Monywa, Myanmar.  Search and rescue operations were deployed, 32 bodies were recovered and more than 85 people are reported still missing.

On the night of October 13 to 14, 2016, the fishing vessel MELISSA III is anchored in the west of the plateau of Rochebonne where he put his nets. October 14 at 3:45, the main engine that ensures the production of energy on board stops. The skipper goes down to access the machine compartment and finds that it is flooded. The bilge pumps, one attached to the main engine and the other to the auxiliary unit, are unusable. The skipper orders each crew member to wear his immersion suit. The distress alert is sent around 4:15. The skipper contacted by VHF the fishing vessels present nearby. The water begins to overflood the kitchen and the accomodation. Unable to fight against the flood, the skipper decides to abandon the ship at 4:20. Life rafts are deployed. Two sailors board the first raft. The engineer falls to the sea while attempting to climb the raft closest to the ship. When the skipper decides to leave the vessel, the rafts are removed from the ship, he throws himself into the sea. Shortly before 5:00, two fishing vessels arrive on scene: PETIT GAL and AMAZONE. They recover the four survivors. The MELISSA III sunk at 6:00.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

Location: LIAODONG WAN 9 MILES SW OF YINGKOU
SummaryOfEvents: In collision with unknown ship, stranded and subsequently sank in Liaodong Wan 9 miles SW of Yingkou. Bunker fuel and other pollutants were removed by salvors by 18/11/16. The wreck was removed by 14/08/17.

Caught fire in the engine room whilst undergoing repairs at a shipyard at Guasmo, Guayaquil. All shipyard workers were evacuated. Three sustained injuries and were taken to local hospitals for medical attention. The blaze spread to the entire ship and was eventually brought under control by local fire services 4 hours later. The ship was completely burnt out.

The tug ran aground on 13 October west of Bella Bella, B.C., Canada.  Two tanks containing oil or contaminants were either torn open or severely damaged.  Booms were deployed to try to contain the spill.  Bad weather hampered efforts but the containment system was replaced. The tug is resting in 9 metres of water in a channel about 500 kms north of Vancouver.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 12.10.2016, while under tow by the sea-going “MERKURIY” tug in the Black Sea, an ingress of sea water into ship spaces was detected on board the self-propelled “ASPTR-1” crane ship (hereinafter referred to as SPCS “ASPTR-1”) by its crew. The SPCS “ASPTR-1”, which at that time had on its board a shore emergency & rescue team and a part of the crew, proceeded with emergency operations to maintain the ship’s survivability.  
At 02:00 a.m. the SPCS “ASPTR-1” lost its buoyancy and foundered in the site with co-ordinates: φ=44˚26.3΄Ν; λ=034˚11.8΄Ε, abeam of the Yalta City in 3.2 nautical miles off the coast at a water depth of 78 m. Five crew members were rescued by the “DERZKIY” sea-going tug, three hands were missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: After fishing operation in the morning, in the North-East of BREHAT Island the trawler/shell dredger L'ENFANT D'ARVOR on the way back to Saint-Quay Portrieux harbour hit sunken rocks LES ECHAUDEES. The fishing vessel foundered vrey quickly. The two crew members just had time to launch the liferaft and to jump in the water without lifejacket or immersion suit. One of the crew drifted away an cannot reach the liferaft. The other crew succeeded to climb inside the liferaft and sent out a distress signal . BREHAT signal station relayed to MRCC for search and rescue operation. The crew member inside the liferaft was recovered by a fishing vessel in the vicinity. The crew who drifted away was recovered one hour later unconscious .

SummaryOfEvents: The ship struck the pier whilst moored at Puerto la Cruz, Venezuela. It sustained damage to the hull, took on water and developed a list to port. Local authorities effected temporary repairs and pumping out. No injuries or pollution were reported. The vessel had been laid up for several years awaiting disposal, and will be sold for recycling.

Wind force 7 from NNW. Pilot was on board and recommend tug, but master refuse. Ship manoeuvre area has been narrow. On the end moor manoeuver ship "Maria Theresa" get damage stern port quarter and damaged little the quay.

On 5 October 2016 at about 10:30, the second bridge officer and a seaman on the ship AL ANDALUS EXPRESS were conducting routine checks of the fast rescue boat. As aprt of these checks, they proceeded to lower it using the emergency procedure. As they operated the lowering mechanism, the boat fell freely from aheight of about twenty meters with two persons aboard. Both crewmembers were injured and were taken to a hospital with back pain.

At 1812 on 5 October 2016, a sea pilot, was attempting to board a general cargo vessel from the pilot launch when he fell and was crushed between the two vessels. Despite prompt medical attention, he died at the scene. The accident occurred during a routine changeover of pilots at the boarding station, which marked the boundary for two pilotage areas. Due to the choppy seas, the outbound general cargo vessel had created a lee for the pilot launch to facilitate the boarding process. The difference in freeboard between the two vessels was varying between about 30cm and 130cm. A pilot ladder had been rigged, but the sea pilot attempted to board by stepping up and through an open gate in the railings onto the main deck which, although adjacent to the ladder, did not form part of the vessels designated pilot boarding arrangements.

On October 4,2016, while the crew members of the fishing vessel JUAN Y VIRGILIO were handling the fishing gear, the fishing vessel suffered a blow from the sea. The impact originated a leak in the stern. Unable to control the leak with their own means, the skipper asked for help to the Maritime Authorities. The rescue boat SALVAMAR SIRIUS arrived at the side of the fishing vessel and one of its crew embarked on it with a waterpump to drain away the water. The fishing vessel was towed by the rescue boat to the port of Sant Feliu de Guixols, where it was repaired.The cause of the leak was the poor condition of the structure in the aft area. Contributing factors are the poor maintenance of the hull structure.

La Nave GAZ FRATERNITY arribó el día 29 de agosto de 2016 a las 0400 hrs (LT) al área de fondeo de Topolobampo (Sinaloa – México) aproximadamente a 10 millas de la costa, con el fin de poder realizar sus operaciones de descarga de GAS PROPANO. La embarcación prolonga su estadía en México por motivos de falta de disponibilidad de almacenaje en la Terminal de Pemex en Topolobampo – México.
El día 2 de octubre de 2016, en horas de la mañana el Primer Oficial realiza la reunión diaria con el Contramaestre, para asignar los trabajos que se realizarían en cubierta, el cual consistía en abrir los registros de los tanques de lastres altos No. 3 (babor y estribor) y  la escotilla del ducto de líneas para entrar y realizar la abertura de los tanques de doble fondo no. 3 (babor y estribor). Esto lo designa el Primer Oficial con el fin de poder inspeccionar dichos tanques pues ya estaba en la programación de mantenimiento. 
El Contramaestre le indica visualmente al personal de cubierta (marinos y cadete), los registros y escotilla que deberían abrir.  Una de las escotillas fue abierta erróneamente, puesto que esta era la escotilla del espacio de bodega del tanque no.1, el cual era un espacio inerte. El cadete entra al espacio de bodega sin autorización ni precaución y queda inconsciente. El contramaestre hace el hallazgo y trata de rescatarlo pero igualmente queda inconsciente. Luego, uno de los marinos nota la ausencia, encuentra al cadete y al contramaestre desmayados dentro del espacio, no toma las precauciones pertinentes para entrar ni da la voz de alerta y entra para realizar el rescate pero no fue satisfactorio pues queda inconsciente dentro del lugar, siendo 3 víctimas dentro de dicho espacio. 
Es entonces donde otro de los marinos que se encuentra en el cuarto de compresores, retorna a la cubierta y nota la ausencia del personal; decide aproximarse a la escotilla que se encontraba abierta, notando que habían 3 cuerpos desmayados dentro del espacio, dando la alerta al primer oficial. 
El primer oficial junto con otros miembros de la tripulación realizaron el rescate lo más rápido posible, aplicando los primeros auxilios correspondientes, de los cuales 2 recobraron la conciencia, pero el cadete falleció.
The ship was involved in an unknown casualty incident at Pasir Gudang, Malaysia and was subsequently sold for recycling in December 2016.

SOLASStatus: NORD GARDENIA: Unknown/unspecified, SKAWLINK III: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
During transfer of personel while the Danish tanker was anchored off Skagen (The Skaw) in Kattegat, Denmark, a superintendent representing the engine manufacturer fell over board. The accident happened at the time when the superintendent stepped onto the pilot ladder from the launch.
The man was rescued from the Water some 20 minutes later and ressusitation was attempted. The person was later pronounced dead by the assisting Medical staff from a rescue helicopter.

On the morning of 25 September 2016 a ro-ro passenger ferry suffered a propulsion control failure on approach to its berth. The port shaft controllable pitch propeller failed at 50% ahead causing the ferry to lose control and run aground in the harbour. The failure occurred when the ferry was approximately four minutes away from the berth and traveling at 12 knots. The master who had control of the ferry attempted to diagnose the cause of the failure and use the ferry s starboard shaft controllable pitch propeller and bow thruster to bring the ferry back under control. Using a combination of the manoeuvring controls and stopping the port shaft from rotating the ferry eventually came to a stop in the water after having run over a marina pontoon. As the ferry s forward motion ceased the starboard side of the hull came in to contact with submerged rocks, damaging the bilge keel and causing indentations to the hull plating. When manoeuvring back towards its intended berth the ferry s starboard propeller became entangled in the upturned pontoon mooring chain. The ferry eventually berthed at the linkspan on the jetty and the passengers and vehicles were discharged. The ferry remained alongsde for three days during which an underwater survey was completed to assess the damage and to identify the cause of the failure of the port controllable pitch propeller. The ferry eventually sailed for a ship repair yard on the port shaft only.

SYNOPSIS September 23rd, 2016 at 16:00 UTC the PICACHO tug started towing the barge CAPITAN PRIMERO from the port of Arrecife (Lanzarote) to El Puerto de Santa Mara (Cdiz), where the barge had to carry out a complete survey to obtain the required international certificates, necessary for carrying out contracted work in Tangiers (Morocco). In the course of the trip, on September 25th around 05:05 UTC, from the tugboat warned that the towing speed was considerably reduced and they stopped seeing the lights of the towed barge. When getting light that morning, the crew found that the towed vessel had capsized. Around 09:35 UTC on the 25th the barge sank. CONCLUSIONS All indications are that the barge CAPTAIN FIRST capsized as a result of a loss of stability caused by the progressive flooding of several of its empty starboard side compartments. It is possible that this entry of water was produced through the very mouths of access to these spaces, either because they were open or because they did not maintain their watertightness throughout the trip. This hypothesis would also explain why the collapse occurred after the capsize.Other causes of flooding cannot be ruled out, as there is no record of the state of the plates inside the hopper or the state of the internal partition bulkheads. It cannot be ruled out either that given the age and the type of stresses endured by the internal structure and plates of the hopper possible structural cracks allowed flooding to progress through the different spaces of the vessel.It is not possible to be sure of the causes of the flooding, since the barge could not be inspected after the accident because it sank to great depths.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
A fire caused by an explosion took place on board the Oil Tanker BURGOS about 8 miles off the coast of Boca del Rio in south eastern Veracruz state on 24 September 2016. 
The cause of the fire remains unknown. The 31 people aboard were able to make it off the ship and get back to shore safely and without injury. 
According to the media, the load was made up of 80,000 barrels of diesel fuel, 71,000 barrels of unleaded gasoline, and 16,000 barrels of desulfurized gasoline. Some of the fuel shipment had spilled from the tanker but didn't pose a risk to the environment.

Location: IONION SEA 26 MILES SE OF SYRACUSE, ITALY
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took on water in the engine room, developed a list to port and capsized whilst underway in the Ionian Sea 26 miles SE of Syracuse, Italy.
All 14 crew abandoned ship to a life raft and were subsequently rescued by Italian coast guard. Anti-pollution vessels attended the scene. No injuries or pollution were reported. The capsized hull remained afloat and was towed.

On September 23, in the port of Lagos, Nigeria, the Bosun was fatally injured during emergency unmooring operation. The Bosun was struck by a mooring line, which he was handling, while he was standing at the forecastle deck starboard side in front of a winch drum. The area where the Bosun was standing was within the snap-back zone of the parted mooring line (Snap-back zones are typically spaces where it is anticipated a failed mooring line could recoil).

Fire alarm activated at bridge. Duty officer was instructed to check to see if it was a false alarm. Smoke emitted from the second engineer cabin. General fire alarm was raised and fire extinguishers were used to combat fire but in vain. Fire team was mustered and combat fire. The fire spread quickly to bridge. No causality but damage to bridge was resulted.

At 11:23 local time on 22nd Sept 2016 while M/v MERCURIA moored/alongside on the quay in Taranto harbour, her was intersted by fire consequently a blast on upper deck. At the moment of the explosion two crew member working on site. As a consequence of the explosion two crew members was injured. Occurrence under investigation.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On Thursday 22 September 2016, at 01:00 local time, a crew member of the fishing ship A TENENCIA fell overboard when he was fishing. At 01:18 the skipper informed the CCS A Corua about the accidente and that they had been able to recover the crew member, and they were practicing resuscitation maneuvers. A rescue helicopter transferred the crew member to the airport of A Corua where there was a medicalized ambulance, but doctors confirmed the death of the crewman.

SOLASStatus: CMA CGM SIMBA: Unknown/unspecified, DOMINGUE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: A tug girted and capsized while asssiting a container ship in unberthing. As a result of the accident, two of the tug's crew died. The tug had been connected to the ship's port quarter to help pull the ship's stern off the berth. During the manoeuvre, the prevailing tidal conditions caused the ship to move towards an outlying mooring dolphin. to avoid striking the dolphin, the ship's master briefly manoeuvred the ship ahead, during which time the tug girted and capsized.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: MURAT HACIBEKIROGLU II, loaded with clinker, was en route from Iskenderun to Darica (Gulf of Kocaeli). Vessel started to be flooded with water in the engine room, which could not be controlled and Master ordered to abandon the ship. M/V ELECTRA A rushed to the site of the accident, after receiving their distress signal and rescued 10 crew members of the vessel, who were inside a rescue boat. MURAT HACIBEKIROGLU II sank totally at 15:36 LT.

On the afternoon of 19 September 2015, a fire started in the fore part of the main deck of the Wan Hai 307 and the crew was unable to get the fire under control.
The incident was reported to local Authorities and the ship proceeded to anchor west of Lamma island, where fire-fighting tugs with special equipment arrived. All
crew members were safely evacuated and fire-fighters boarded the vessel. It was reported that some containers on fire, and others near the fire, carry hazardous
and dangerous cargo.
After several hours the fire was extinguished, but some of the containers were still smoking. The authorities allowed the ship to berth at a quay between Cheung
Chau and Lamma islands. The fire-fighters are monitoring the ship and the effected containers will be offloaded in due course.

On September 15, 2016 at 9:08 p.m passenger vessel JOVEN ANTONIA SEGUNDO, which runs the regular line between Ibiza and Formentera, ran aground on the island of La Torreta (Freus de Ibiza and Formentera). On board the ship were 4 crew members and 7 passengers, none of them was injured. The vessel was refloated by a rescue vessel and arrived by its own means to the port of Ibiza. The ship suffered no significant damage. The accident was caused by the lack of effective monitoring of the navigation, due to an excessof confidence associated with the routine of carrying out the same route several times a day.

The ship was stranded on the seawall after breaking moorings and drifting at Sizihwan, Kaohsiung in typhoon Meranti. The ship sustained severe damage to the hull and subsequently capsized onto the starboard side. During rescue attempts one crew member fell overboard and drowned. The remaining crew was rescued safely. Some oil pollution was reported in the sea. Anti-pollution measures, clean up and removal of bunker oil were effected.

SOLASStatus: FU KUAN NO. 606: Unknown/unspecified, SHUN TIEN NO. 606: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: The ship was stranded on the seawall after breaking moorings and drifting at Sizihwan, Kaohsiung in typhoon Meranti. The ship sustained further damage to the port bow after colliding with Fu Kuan No. 606 that had drifted ashore in the same area and subsequently capsized onto its starboard side. All crew were rescued safely. Some oil pollution was reported in the sea. Anti-pollution measures, clean up and removal of bunker oil were effected.

The ship was stranded on sandbanks after dragging anchor, breaking moorings and drifting off Gugang, Kinmen in typhoon Meranti. No injuries were reported. Sustained holes in no. 3, no. 4 port and no. 3 starboard bunker tanks. Some oil pollution was reported in the sea. Oil boom was laid to contain the spill. Cleanup and removal of bunkers were effected. Inspection and temporary repairs were effected. The ship was under admiralty arrest and anchored off Xiamen, China at the time of the incident. It was refloated on 15/11/16 and towed to Xiamen for inspection. It was then towed to Zhoushan, China in December 2016 for recycling.

Location: Gulf of Aden 3 miles SW of Mukalla
SummaryOfEvents: The ship took on water in the engine room and sank in the Gulf of Aden 3 miles SW of Al Mukalla, Yemen in good weather. It had been at anchor off Al Mukalla waiting to berth at a terminal when it suffered a two meter long crack in the hull in the engine room. The sudden flooding was too much for the ship’s pumps to keep up. The eight crew on board were forced to abandon ship into a life raft while the ship slowly submerged. The Coastguard arrived a short time later and rescued all the crew. There were no reports of injuries. Within a few hours, the ship completely disappeared from the surface and sank.

Location: THE CAKAUYAWA REEF WHILST APPROACHING SUVA
SummaryOfEvents:
Stranded on the Cakauyawa reef whilst approaching Suva.
No injuries or pollution were reported. All 14 crew were rescued by the Fijian navy patrol vessel Kula and taken to Suva. Sustained damage to the hull, developed list to starboard and partially sank. Initial refloating attempts were unsuccessful. Salvors removed bunker oil and other pollutants. If the vessel can be refloated it will be scuttled.
While on passage the Master noted a loss of power. The vessel stopped for an investigation. It was decided there was a rope around the propeller. A tug was called for a tow to a port of refuge.

One person is dead and four are injured, including two whose lives are in danger.
The five were reportedly in the lifeboat when it ‘became detached’ from the ship and fell.
All of those who were on board at the time are Royal Caribbean International staff and there is not though any passengers were injured

Location: South Atlantic Ocean 200 miles SE of Balneario el Condor, Rio Negro, Argentina
SummaryOfEvents: Fire erupted on the stern of the fishing vessel and it subsequently sank in the South Atlantic Ocean 200 miles SE of Balneario el Condor, Rio Negro, Argentina. All 17 crew were rescued by a nearby fishing vessel Atrevido and taken to Mar del Plata. No injuries were reported. A coastguard patrol vessel Thompson attempted to fight the blaze but this spread throughout the ship which sank the following day. Argentine navy beech 350 aircraft PA-22 monitored the scene for pollution.

Location: Off the south of Gobo city, Wakayama Prefecture
SummaryOfEvents: An explosion occurred on the tanker while underway off the south of Gobo city. One Korean crewmember died and two Indonesian were injured.

Location: JAVA SEA 49 MILES E OF TANJUNG MENJANGAN, SUMATERA SELATAN, INDONESIA
SummaryOfEvents: The ship took on water and sank whilst underway in the Java Sea 49 miles E of Tanjung Menjangan, Sumatera Selatan, Indonesia in heavy swells. Local authorities effected SAR operations with patrol boat, KN P486 attending the scene. All 16 crew were rescued by passing Pusri Indonesia. No injuries or pollution were reported. Eight containers went overboard and drifted apart with 2 containers later salvaged.

El buque Aframax River se encontraba descargando crudo en el muelle 3 del Houston Fuel Oil Terminal en Houston, Texas el día 05 de septiembre de 2017. La nave había recalado procedente de Castries, Saint Lucia, el día anterior y las labores de descarga habían tomado menos de 24 hrs. La descarga termina a las 21:30 LT del 5 de septiembre quedando el buque en lastre y en preparación para su zarpe a Pajaritos, México. A las 23:00 LT abordan dos Pilotos pertenecientes a Houston Pilots quienes asesorarán al Capitán de la nave en su tránsito de salida del Houston Ship Channel. La maniobra de desatraque también involucra a dos remolcadores posicionados por la amura y cuadra de babor. A las 23:42 LT se comienzan a soltar las líneas y a las 23:59 el Piloto a cargo de la maniobra ordena máquinas Dead Slow Astern. Transcurridos escasos minutos, el Piloto y el Capitán se percatan que el buque está desarrollando una velocidad mayor de la esperada y a pesar de sus intentos por aplicar medidas para detener la viada del buque, el buque golpea un pilote de amarre ubicado en el Inter-Continental Terminal (al otro lado del canal de navegación). Como resultado del impacto el Aframax River sufre fracturas en su casco babor, particularmente en un tanque de combustible (2 FOT). La fricción del contacto enciende el combustible derramado ocasionando un incendio que prácticamente envuelve el 50% del buque. Gracias a la acción combinada de la tripulación, remolcadora y personal de los terminales, este incendio se controla y el buque es finalmente llevado a la sección de lay-up en las cercanías, en donde atraca a las 03:16 LT del 6 de septiembre de 2017. El accidente no deja heridos, pero sí daños materiales. La investigación concluye que el accidente se debió primordialmente a una falla en el sistema del gobernador de la máquina principal y destaca lecciones aprendidas para futuras referencias.

The ship capsized whilst moored at Westport Marina, Grays Harbor, WA, US. The ship was lying partially submerged with a 45 degree list to starboard. An oil sheen was reported in the water. The coast guard and local harbour authority deployed oil booms and cleanup pads to contain any fuel from the ship. Global diving and salvage sealed vents and removed 3,500 gallons of bunker fuel.

At about 18331 on 2 September 2016, the crewman on board the fishing vessel
Pauline Mary was dragged overboard after becoming entangled in the gear while
shooting pots at fishing grounds east of Hartlepool. When the crewman was
recovered back on board about 20 minutes later, he was not breathing and, despite
the efforts of Pauline Mary’s skipper and the emergency services, could not be
resuscitated.
The skipper had been working Pauline Mary for only 2 days and was laying his pots
for the first time when the accident happened. The skipper’s 7-year-old son and a
female family friend were also on board at the time.
The investigation identified that a safe method of shooting pots had not been
developed on board Pauline Mary. The crewman was also not carrying a knife or
wearing a personal flotation device, both of which could have improved his chances
of survival. It was also not appropriate for the passengers, in particular a child, to
be on board during this fishing operation.

The Maltese registered container vessel Sydney Trader had been anchored OPL at Hong Kong, China since 19 June 2016, awaiting orders for the next charter. At 0730, on 02 September 2016, the chief mate instructed the bosun to continue routine maintenance work in cargo hold no. 2. The chief mate also confirmed that all the Safety Management System (SMS) risk assessments and Permit to Work forms had been completed and signed before the bosun left the bridge at 0750.
At about 0805, five crew members entered cargo hold no. 2 via the manhole aft of Bay 18, Row 4, no. 2 M hatch, above the middle cross section. Soon after, at about 0810, the bosun reported to the chief mate that one of the ordinary seafarer (OS) had fallen down cargo hold no. 2.The bosun also informed the third mate (duty officer) on the bridge. The master was informed of the accident at about 0815.
The chief mate proceeded immediately to the cargo hold to provide first aid and medical assistance. When reaching the tank top, he noticed that the OS was unresponsive, with a serious head wound. He checked for a pulse on the OS’ hand and neck but could not detect any.
The safety investigation found that the immediate cause of the fatal injury was a fall from a height of about 12 m into the cargo hold.

Local authorities dispatched a tug to the scene which towed the vessel to Naples, Italy. For safety reasons, all passengers and some crew were evacuated by the fast ferry Isola di Vulcano and disembarked in Naples.

On Monday the 29th of August 2016, a Deck Rating serving on board the commercial motor yacht MEAMINA failed to report for duty after having gone
swimming from the vessel while it was lying at anchor off Cannes, France.
The Chief Officer and Deck Rating whilst off duty performed a series of exercises on the foredeck. They then proceeded to dive from the bow of the
vessel and swim to the stern. Both men then completed a number of free dives under the stern of the vessel and on completion of such, the Chief
Officer left the water. The Deck Rating remained in the water alone and he was observed to complete a series of breathing exercises before proceeding
to free dive under the length of vessel.
The Deck Rating was required to be back on duty at 20:00 hrs and his absence was noted at about 20:20 hrs when he failed to respond to radio calls. This consequently led to the vessel being searched to ascertain his whereabouts.
About 20:45 the vessels Master was informed that the Deck Rating could not be located on board and that there were concerns that he had not returned
after having gone swimming earlier that evening. The Master ordered a detailed search of the vessel, informed the local Emergency Services and contacted the vessels ISM Management Company using the 24h emergency telephone number.
Local search and rescue authorities conducted a search of the area using a search and rescue helicopter and other vessels. An underwater search was also carried out but poor visibility hampered the operation. The search was suspended about 02:00 hrs on Tuesday morning.
A further underwater search was conducted and at 15:50 hrs on 01st September the Deck Ratings body was found on the seabed by divers searching in the vicinity of where the vessel had been at anchor.

Two tugs proceeded to the scene with a diving team. The vessel was being assisted by another tug MB-344 at the time of the incident. Bunker fuel was removed and cargo discharged via a temporary jetty. The damage was beyond economical repair and so the ship is to be recycled in situ.

Location: Voyage From Durban South Africa to Mundra India
SummaryOfEvents:
POLONIA departed from Durban, South Africa on 20 April 2015 at approximately 1348hrs (LT). While underway to Mundra, India, on the morning of 23 April 2015, the engineering officers and ratings reported for duty in the Engine Control Room (ECR) as part of their normal daily routine. All members of the engineering team were present except for the ship’s Electrician, Mr. Novica Marojevic. At approximately 0830hrs (LT), when the engine crew was unable to easily locate Mr. Marojevic, the general alarm was sounded and the vessel’s crew was mustered so that a thorough search of the vessel could be conducted. 

At 1000hrs (LT), the search of the vessel completed and the Electrician was not located onboard. A distress message (PAN PAN) was transmitted, look outs were posted, and the vessel altered to her reciprocal course to search for Mr. Marojevic. A second search onboard the vessel was commenced.

At 1106hrs (LT), the vessel received notification via the Inmarsat-C that MRCC Cape Town was designated as the assisting Rescue Coordination Center (RCC). Searches onboard the vessel continued throughout the day and once the position where Mr. Marojevic was last seen onboard had been reached, a search pattern was commenced with assistance from MRCC Cape Town and vessels BERLIAN EKUATOR and LIA. 

At 0245hrs (LT) on 25 April 2015, the search and rescue operation was suspended under the guidance of MRCC Cape Town, and POLONIA resumed her voyage to Mundra, India. Mr. Marojevic was not located.

SOLASStatus: ANGELA ARCELLA: Unknown/unspecified, MARIA: Unknown/unspecified, UNION: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 1206 on 09 August 2016, the Antigua & Barbuda registered motor vessel (MV) Maria made heavy contact with the Italian registered fishing vessel (FV) Angela Arcella and the Democratic Republic of Congo registered MV Union in the port of Valletta, Malta. 
Maria was under pilotage and was preparing to berth at Laboratory Wharf. Union was safely moored alongside at Magazine Wharf, whereas FV Angela Arcella was also alongside at Ras Ħanzir. 
On her final approach to the quay, Maria failed to stop in time and struck Angela Arcella. The bulbous bow penetrated the fishing vessel’s hull below the water line. Soon after the allision, Maria gained considerable sternway and struck Union on her stern. Consequently, the mooring ropes parted and Union was set adrift in the harbour. Maria was finally brought under control and secured at Magazine Wharf. Meanwhile, another pilot boarded Union and with the assistance of a tug boat, berthed her at Laboratory Wharf. 
Both Maria and Union sustained structural damage. Angela Arcella reported progressive flooding and consequently lost her reserve buoyancy and foundered at its berth. No injuries and pollution were reported as a result of this accident. 
The Marine Safety Investigation Unit (MSIU) concluded that the immediate cause of the allision was the slow response of the controllable pitch propeller (CPP) system. Recommendations have been made to the managers of Maria and Transport Malta’s Ports and Yachting Directorate with respect to the CPP system, vessel movement and pilot/master communication and interaction, and timely communication of berth plans.

Local authorities organized a large scale search and rescue operation, engaging nearby freighters and navy helicopters. The Guo Shun 21 suffered some damage in the bow area but remained afloat.

On 5th.August 2016 at 0030lt, Liberian Registered MORNING IBIS collided with MORHOLMEN at Malacca Strait ,near one fathom bank Latitude 03-03.2N Longitude 100-46.9E.  Visibility was good, slight sea. Vessel FWD 5.6m, AFT 8.1m.

SOLASStatus: DREAM II: SOLAS, MSC ALEXANDRA: SOLAS
Location: 1.6NM SOUTH EAST OFF SEBAROK ISLAND, SINGAPORE TERRITORIAL WATERS
SummaryOfEvents: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) was notified of a collision involving crude oil tanker Dream II (164241 gt, built 2008) and fully cellular containership MSC Alexandra (153115 gt, built 2010) in the Singapore Strait, about 3 km south-east of Sebarok Island at about 2355, Aug 3. Prior to the incident, MPA's Port Operations Control Centre provided traffic information and alerted the shipmasters of Dream II and MSC Alexandra of the risk of collision. Dream II sustained damage to her bow whilst MSC Alexandra sustained damages on her port quarter hull. Both vessels are in stable condition and safely anchored in Singapore. MSC Alexandra reported that 10 empty containers fell overboard during the incident, four onto the deck of Dream II and the rest into the water.

A deckhand on board a twin rig prawn trawler was seriously injured after being struck on the head by a steel pole during the recovery of fishing gear that had become caught on an underwater obstruction. The deckhand was knocked unconscious and was transferred by helicopter to hospital. He suffered serious, life-changing injuries and will require medical care for the foreseeable future. The investigation identified that: The deckhand was struck by a guide-pole that had been propelled from its socket by the force exerted from the port trawl s wire bridle acting in conjunction with the vessel s motion. The guide-pole arrangement was not constructed to be weight bearing. The injured deckhand was standing in a dangerous position and his head was not protected by a safety helmet. Non-compliance with a number of regulatory requirements had the potential to compromise the safety of the vessel and its crew. The underwater obstruction caught by the trawler was possibly the wreck of another fishing vessel, and the wreck s position as shown on Admiralty charts might be inaccurate.

SOLASStatus: CMS DENIZ: SOLAS, TOPAZ ARROW: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: The “Israfil Huseynov” pipe layer ship performed the pipe laying operation in the coordinates at 39°51.000' N, 50° 23.000' E in the sector of the Caspian Sea belonging to the Azerbaijan Republic together with “CMS Deniz” at about 09:00 on August 02, 2016. Based on the permission given by “Israfil Huseynov”, a change operation of the crew of “Topaz Arrow” was planned by mooring to “CMS Deniz”; “Topaz Arrow” started to proceed, at about 10:05, entered into anchorage area of “Israfil Huseynov” and made to moor to the port side of “CMS Deniz”. Afterwards “Topaz Arrow” collided with a blow to the port side of “CMS Deniz” between 90th and 95th frames with the ship’s bow while a mooring operation at about 10:10. As a result of collision, the construction of ships was damaged and ships remained fit to proceed.

Fishing trawler caught (fishing) shrimps in the fishing area at the Barents sea.
02.08.2016 at 04:50 time UTC captain on the bridge to began to haul bottom trawl. When approach otter door disconnected warp gear and trawl began to haul with cable winch. The trawler speed there was dead slow ahed. In this moment breakaged left side cable winch and the captain solve take backet bobbins with one starboard side cable winch. Nets slack was got and trawl nets upon on the propeller.
After this the ship has been towing to port of Batsfjord (Norway) in shipyard to repair.

On 02/08/2016 the vessel TIDE NAVIGATOR was berthed in the port of Villanueva y Geltr. Early in the morning the captain start the manoeuvre to leave the port. During the manoeuvre the pilot was on board and one tug near the vessel. The captain neither required the assistance of the tug nor followed the advices of the pilot. Few minutes later the vessel contacted the breakwater.

At about 1604 on 31 July 2016, the chief engineer on board SCA Munksund was hit by flying debris following the disintegration of the flexible coupling between the power take-off from the main engine gearbox and the input to the shaft generator.
The chief engineer was seriously injured, sustaining amputation of his right hand from below the middle of his forearm. He also suffered other injuries to his face.
The vessel sought medical assistance from the Swedish Rescue Centre and the injured crew member was lifted ashore by helicopter.
The Marine Safety Investigation Unit (MSIU) found that immediately prior to the accident, the flexible coupling between the main engine gearbox power take-off and the shaft generator had been incorrectly disassembled (split), following failure of the shaft generator.
Moreover, the safety investigation revealed that the context in which the chief engineer and his sub-ordinates were operating, was intricate enough that possible options were actually either not observed or else not deemed feasible to be considered.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The ship's Chief Officer fell overboard from the bridge wing.  No one reported witnessing the incident.
fire on board
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Off Aleutian Islands in the Bering Sea
SummaryOfEvents: Merchant ships rescued 46 people from a sinking fishing boat off Alaska's Aleutian Islands in the Bering Sea. When the 220-foot Alaska Juris started taking on water, crewmembers radioed for help and abandoned the ship, getting on three rafts. The Spar Canis and the Vienna Express and two other ships responded to an emergency alert. The cutter Midgett, two C-130 transport planes and two helicopters were also dispatched to the scene. Seas were calm, and no injuries were reported. The incident occurred about 700 miles off the Alaskan coast and 150 miles northwest of Adak Island. Spar Canis recovered 28 people from two rafts and the Vienna Express rescued another 18 from a third raft.

At about 1408 (UTC +2) on 25 July 2016, the Maltese registered passenger ship Horizon ran aground on the rocky bank  Plentinggrunnen soon after departing her berth in Stavanger, Norway.  At the time of the accident, she had 1615 passengers and 612 crew members on board.  The vessel, whose forward draught was 7.55 m, grounded on a marked shoal that was charted at 5.3 m.

Following the grounding, the vessel used her own propulsion to come off the shoal but these attempts were unsuccessful.  The master then requested the assistance of a tug, which was able to pull her off the shoal.  Horizon was able to re-berth and assess the damage.

The vessel sustained hull damage to the port side bottom and keel forward.  This consisted of ruptures to the forepeak tank and the ballast water deep tank no. 2.  Temporary underwater repairs were made to the vessel and Horizon was able to sail after 30 hours to complete her cruise.

The safety investigation concluded that the grounding occurred because the planned swing of the vessel s bow to port was initiated early.

On the 20 July 2016 the Bahamas registered passenger ship NORWEGIAN BREAKAWAY was berthed starboard (stbd) side alongside at the Heritage Wharf, Bermuda. During the course of the stay in port the Port Side Fast Rescue Craft (FRC) was launched as part of a combined man overboard (MOB) and oil spill response drill.  The rescue boat was hoisted at 1042:55. In the first attempt at stowing the rescue boat, the rescue boat did not fully come to its normal stowed position. At 1044:14 a second attempt to bring the rescue boat to its fully stowed position at 1044:30, however, during this attempt the wire parted causing the FRC to fall at 1044:37.
The rescue boat fell to the water, landing upside down, two crew members fell clear of the boat and sustained minor injuries which were treated by the ship’s medical personnel. These two individuals remained on active duty.
The other two crew members struck the rescue boat as they fell, both sustaining serious injuries. Once recovered they were evacuated to the Bermuda King Edward Memorial Hospital where one crewman was declared deceased shortly after arrival and the other was stabilized and medically evacuated to the USA. This crewmember succumbed to complications and was declared deceased some weeks later.

The ship caught fire in the bridge area whilst berthed at Vieste.
The blaze spread to the rest of the ship which was completely burnt out before being extinguished by local fire services. No injuries were reported. An investigation was effected. The reported fire was the result of an arson attack.

At 1252 on 19 July 2016, two passenger carrying rigid inflatable boats, Osprey and Osprey II, collided in the Firth of Forth. A passenger who was sitting on an inflatable tube of Osprey II was crushed between Osprey s bow and Osprey II s helm console, resulting in her sustaining serious injuries.
Both RIBs had departed from Anstruther Harbour and were bound for the Isle of May. While proceeding in parallel at a speed of around 6 knots, the skipper of each RIB increased speed and commenced a power turn away from each other with the intention of passing each other in the course of completing a round turn. However, as the RIBs turned towards each other, it became apparent to both skippers that the RIBs were in danger of colliding. Although they both acted quickly to reduce the speed of their respective vessels and so lessen the impact, they were unable to prevent the collision.

Location: Port of Jakarta JICT Berth No.1, Indonesia.
InitialEvent: Stevedore was crushed to death by a hoisting container while loading cargo.
SummaryOfEvents: On 19 July 2016 at about 1155 hours, on board the Hong Kong, China registered container ship CSCL SAN JOSE, while loading containers at the berth No.1 of the port of Jakarta, Indonesia.  An operator assistant from the quay stevedore company contractor was crushed to death by lowering a forty-foot empty container to its planned stack position on deck of the ship operating by the shore quay crane.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Sea Port of Gdańsk (Republic of Poland)
SummaryOfEvents: On July 18 2016, the ODISSEY tugboat stood anchored on the roadstead of the Sea Port of Gdańsk (Republic of Poland). At 14:55, while pulling-in the towing line on board the tug, the pulling rope slipped from the bitt and hit the ODISSEY’s Boatswain against his chest, thus causing to him an injury incompatible with human life.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Manila Bay off Roxas Boulevard, Manila
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took on water, developed a list to port and sank in Manila Bay off Roxas Boulevard, Manila, in good weather.
All 7 crew left the vessel the previous evening as they were unable to contain the flooding. No injuries were reported. The ship had been laid up since 2011 since being detained on alleged arms smuggling charges.

Location: Eden channel off Isla Perro Chico, Sanblas Islands
SummaryOfEvents:
Sustained port main engine failure and stranded on a reef in the Eden channel off Isla Perro Chico, Sanblas Islands, Panama.
No injuries or pollution were reported. Sustained damage to hull and took water in the engine room. All crew were rescued. Local authorities removed 2,530 gallons of diesel fuel. Further salvage attempts are unlikely as the vessel was uninsured. The incident occurred whilst the vessel was attempting to tow 16 metre catamaran ferry Jaqueline from the same reef where she had previously stranded.

On 16th.July 2016 at 10:55Lt, Liberian Registered Navigator Gusto was collided by sludge barge ECOFRIEND at Gibraltar anchorage while vessel anchored at Gibraltar inner anchorage Latitude 36-07.5 N Longitude 005-21.8W. Wind SE force 3, Sea slight and visibility was Good.
An Engine cadet fell overboard across the English Channel around 8 PM on July 15, 2016 while he was doing his internship at HACI FATMA ANA vessel belonging to BAYTAS SHIPPING at Istanbul, Turkey.

SOLASStatus: HOSHO MARU: Unknown/unspecified, YAMATO MARU No. 8: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Seto Inland Sea off Himeji, Hyogo Prefecture
SummaryOfEvents:
Two cargo ships collided in the Seto Inland Sea off Himeji, Hyogo Prefecture, killing two men (the captain and an engineer on the same ship) and injuring another. The injuries sustained were minor.
The ship collided with the Hoshou Maru, capsized and sank near Ieshima Island. 
Five people aboard the Hoshou Maru were unhurt, and the vessel sailed to Himeji port after the accident, the coast guard said.
The weather was fine in the area at the time of the collision.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Sustained explosion in cargo tank whilst undergoing repairs in drydock at the Binh An shipyard, Hai Phong. Six shipyard workers sustained serious burn injuries and were taken to local hospitals. An investigation was effected. The extent of damage is unknown. Reported explosion caused by ignition of methane gas remnants in tank during welding operations.

Location: CARIBBEAN SEA 30 MILES E OF ISLA DE GUANAJA
SummaryOfEvents: The ship sank in the Caribbean Sea 30 miles E of Isla de Guanaja, Honduras on 12/07/16 in heavy weather. One crew member died. The remaining crew were rescued by a passing fishing vessel and taken to Sangrelaya, Honduras.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
According to master's report, master of the vessel was attended there with 2nd officer and AB  in bridge at time 18.00. After this, AB  come to bridge and informed master that one oiler was missing at time 18.40. He immediately has informed engine room and all crew to search full ship, cabin and engine room. After that he has given order to make Williamson Turn operation at time 18.40 at position Lat 14*34'00N and Long 51*30'20E and changed course from 058* to 238* and immediately broadcast the information on VHF device on channel 16 on that he has given the vessel's MOB position for all ships. SOLASStatus: ROYAL IRIS OF THE MERSEY: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
A domestic passenger ferry with 66 passengers and 9 crew on board, grounded on the submerged remains of a mooring dolphin when approaching a lock.
Both of the ferry’s engines stopped but the crew quickly let go an anchor. 
The ferry’s starboard engine was soon re-started but its port engine was disabled. The port propeller, shaft, stern seal and rudder were damaged. 
A minor flood in the shaft space was contained using onboard equipment and the ferry was able to safely manoeuvre and make fast alongside another vessel on a nearby quay. There were no injuries and there was no pollution.

On 08 July 2016, while vessel departed from Ponta De Madeira, Brazil to Hamburg, Germany, about 1805Lt,  the Assistant Electrical Officer informed to the Officer on Watch (OOW) on the bridge that the 2nd Engineer, was unable to locate, the general alarm sounded at 1810Lt. The vessel's crew mustered and thorough search of the vessel was conducted. At 1845 hours LT, the vessel turned to her reciprocal course at position: Lat 01-18.7N, Long 042-12.6W.

The ship was stranded in Oprichnik Bay at Kamenka. Nine crew were rescued by a nearby fishing vessel whilst the captain remained on board to assist with salvage attempts. No injuries were reported. Sustained 2 cracks in hull and took water in the engine room. Some oil leaked into the sea. Anti-pollution booms were deployed. Tug 'Svetlomor-3' attended the scene. Salvors removed 8,800 litres of bunker fuel. The ship was damaged beyond economical repair and was broken up.
Consequences1: Pollution,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:

While berthing the aft spring line parted and hit 2 members of the shore mooring gang.
