SummaryOfEvents: M/V CRYSTALGATE departed from Campa, Vietnam on 03 July 2016, to Villanueva, Philippine. On 04 Jul 2016 about 1320hrs Lt, Crystalgate was involved in collision with fishing boat (QB93917) with (7) Vietnamese crew members onboard at latitude 17-39.5N Longitude 108-11.5E, weather reported as moderate to rough sea with visibility 5 NM. The fishing boat sank and all 7 Vietnamese crews were rescued.

The Bahamas registered passenger vessel Black Watch departed from Dover on Saturday 25th June 2016, on a 13-night ‘Portuguese Island & Cities’ cruise when a fire was reported in the ship's auxiliary engine room. At the time of the incident (01 July 2016), the vessel had left Ponta Delgada in the Azores enroute to Madeira, Portugal when the fire broke out. The fire was later extinguished by the crew with no related casualties or injuries to either passenger or crew. As a result of the fire, three (3) of the ship's auxiliary engines, out of a total of seven which generated electrical power were damaged, affecting lighting and communications onboard.  The Black Watch also suffered a loss of propulsion and developed a reported port list of 3° which stabilised soon after the event.                             

Two main engines were later restored to full power and the ship continued to its next scheduled port of call, Madeira, arriving on Saturday 02nd July 2016 where repair work and a Flag State marine safety investigation commenced. The majority of passengers were flown home via private charter aircrafts.  

At the time of the incident there were 365 crew onboard and  696 guests, the majority of whom were British nationals.

During preparation for sea an AB got his right foot stuck in a winch drum for securing a steel lashing wire. He injured three toes. Received first aid on-board before being sent shore side to local hospital. Was signed off on sick leave.

Location: Gulf of Thailand 8 miles w of Chon Buri
SummaryOfEvents: The ship caught fire after an explosion in the cargo tank whilst undergoing tank cleaning in the gulf of Thailand 8 miles w of Chon Buri. The blaze was extinguished 1 hour later. 4 crew sustained injuries, 1 of whom was very seriously injured and was taken ashore to Chon Buri for hospital treatment. No pollution was reported. The ship did not sustain serious damage.

The cargo ship, a Panama-registered container vessel, was leaving Beira and heading to the Port of Durban. the hull of the Macuti was badly damaged in the collision and water began pouring into the vessel.

InitialEvent: Occupational, Crew member fell from height (permanent means of access platform) to tanktop  of No.3 cargo hold.
SummaryOfEvents: In the morning of 24 June 2016, while the vessel was en route in North Pacific Ocean to Kalama, USA from Busan, S'Korea under ballast condition, the AB fell down to the tank top to his death from the elevated PMA platform passageway in the cargo hold No.3 when he was rinsing the hold by jetting high pressurized water.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The M/V "REGINA MED on 24/06/2016, at 09:47LT, during berthing operatio n in good weather conditions, no current and very good visibility, came into contact with its berth, bow-on. On the Navigation Bridge were a Pilot, the Master and the Second Officer (2/O). In the Engine Control Room (ECR), were the Chief Engineer (C/E) and the Second Engineer (2/E). A fender was completely destroyed and the berth s cement construction behind the fender, sustained damage. The vessel suffered damage on the bow and forecastle area and the fore peak tank (FPT) was holed. There was no pollution caused and no-one was injured. The Port State Control (PSC) of Cyprus, detained the vessel. Temporary repairs were carried out. Condition of Class was imposed by Class Society (RINA). The vessel was released by PSC, on 30/06/2016 at 18:30 LT, with condition to proceed, (under Class conditions), not later than 05/07/2016, for permanent repairs, directly to a repair yard at Chalkis-Greece.

00:15 ship time on the bridge kicked the notification of a fire an automated system. The watch mate in wink send a watch sailor check signal location on board. Watch sailor by VHF radio notified from signal location position to the mate that smoke goes from one freight car. Watch mate after hearing a report from watch sailor immediately informed the ship captain and ch. engineer about the event. 00:20 ship time by captain order activated the fire-extinguishing drenching system in position areas No. 3 and No. 4 and crew deck fire extinguishing part commenced to extinguish the fire hoses support. 00:40 a.m. fire was extinguished. That in itself is the cause of the fire is a freight hot coals packaged in packages.

A deckhand on a scallop dredger was attempting to unhook a dredge bag from the automatic tipping door when he fell overboard. Although he was recovered on board very quickly, he did not show any visible signs of life. The crew carried out cardio pulmonary resuscitation until he was evacuated by helicopter and taken to a hospital nearby. He was declared deceased at the hospital.

On the 21 June 2016, Giannutri was requested by the shipyard to perform extra cleaning in cargo oil tank (COT) no. 2 port in preparation for extensive hot works necessary to replace several steel structures. 

The extra cleaning in COT no. 2 port was assigned to an OS and two painters. An AB joined later. None of the personnel who were assigned this work was involved in the  toolbox meeting.

After the afternoon coffee break, the OS and the AB assigned to work in the COT made their way, to the main deck in preparation to access the COT.

During the entry into the COT, the OS fell a height of about 14.0 m, from the top ladder down to the COT tank top, sustaining fatal injuries.

On June 21, 2016, during the vessel passage from Jeddah, Saudi Arabia to Fujairah, Saudi Arabia approximate position Lat 16-57.4 N Long 040-49.0 E, the Master, and his crews were trying to pump out the un-pumpable oil cargo from Cargo Tank No 3 Starboard by using Air Driven Wilden Pump.
The Chief Officer who noted the malfunctioning pump and re-entered to the tank along with Bosun with full Personal Protecting Equipment. At about 1100 LT,  Master ordered all of them to come up on deck to rest. While they came up, Chief Officer’s Life Line gt entangled with Air Hose from the Wilden Pump, The Bosun who was behind the Chief Officer, noted that Chief Officer removed his face mask and tried to free the entangled lifeline had collapsed in the tank. Master and Crews brought the Chief Officer out from tank by Safet Harness and CPR administered. Chief Officer was unconscious with a weak pulse. Vessel diverted to nearest port Gizan, Saudi Arabia. The Port authority boarded the vessel and carried out an investigation. The Chief Officer passed away at the hospital at 0500 LT on  June 22, 2016.

The Fishing Vessel “Pioneer” was a 23.8 meter long, sea going fishing vessel. The vessel left Georgetown, Guyana on 15th October 2015 on an extended fishing voyage.  The vessel was to be supported and supplied by a mother vessel when on the fishing grounds.  On the morning of 20th June 2016 the vessel experienced a serious fire in the engine room.  The Pioneer crew members abandoned the vessel and took to a life raft in the Atlantic Ocean hundreds of miles from the nearest land. The crew were rescued by a passing bulk carrier with one loss of life and one serious injury.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
At about 2145 on 19 June 2016, an engineer from the container vessel HS Rossini, was fatally injured when he fell on the deck of bunker barge Smit Bongani.
HS Rossini had arrived in Durban, South Africa for container operations. While at berth, barge Smit Bongani manoeuvred alongside HS Rossini to supply bunkers. The bunker hose was connected and the third engineer climbed down the pilot ladder to read the fuel flow meter. On his way back, he fell off the pilot ladder to the deck of Smit Bongani and sustained fatal head injuries.
The cause of the fall was neither related to the vessel’s operations nor to defects in the ladder, which was being used. However, the safety investigation analysed the situation from the perspective of missing barriers which would have otherwise prevented the fall to the barge.

Location: IN THE JAVA SEA 80 MILES SE OF KUMAI, PANGKALANBUUN
SummaryOfEvents: The ship took on water and sank in the Java Sea 80 miles SE of Kumai, Pangkalanbuun in heavy weather.  Eleven crew were rescued by local fishing vessels. One crew member died and two are missing. SAR operation was effected by coastguard, naval and other vessels.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: IN THE FLORES SEA 46 MILES NE OF PULAU KOMODO
SummaryOfEvents: The ship caught fire and subsequently drifted in the Flores Sea 46 miles NE of Pulau Komodo. Attempts by the crew to extinguish the blaze were unsuccessful. Sustained major damage resulting in the disabling of the vessel. No injuries were reported. All 18 crew were transferred to passing MV 'Meratus Dili' and taken to Tanjung Perak, Indonesia where they were handed over to the port authorities. An inspection was effected.

Location: TYRRHENIAN SEA 18 MILES NW OF GIOIA TAURO
SummaryOfEvents: The ship caught fire in the engine room in the Tyrrhenian Sea 18 miles NW of Gioia Tauro. All 13 crew abandoned ship to the barge that the tug was pushing at the time of the incident. No injuries were reported. No reports of pollution released. The crew were subsequently rescued by the coast guard patrol vessel 'CP 827' and taken ashore. The blaze spread to the superstructure of the tug and was extinguished the following day with assistance from coast guard vessels and tugs. Sustained severe damage to the engine room and superstructure. Towed to Genoa, Italy for inspection and repairs.

The Liberian-flagged ship, crewed by 23 seafarers, was on its way from the Indian port of Paradip to the port of Durban, South Africa, when it ran aground off the coast of Mauritius. The ship had onboard a consignment of 147 MT of IFO 380  CST and 39 Mt of diesel oil in its Holds.
A spill of bilge oil has occurred and swept 1.4km of coast at the site were the ship has ran aground.

The ship struck the pier and partially sank whilst arriving at Stromboli on 16/06/16 in heavy weather.  All 117 passengers and 6 crew abandoned ship to life rafts and were rescued by local emergency services. No injuries or pollution were reported. Coastguard AW-139 helicopter attended the scene. Sustained damage to port bow and took water, forward section was almost completely submerged. Bunkers were removed by salvors and refloated using a mobile crane, and taken away on a barge for disposal.

During mooring operations in port of Kapellskar on 16th of June (weather forecast N-NE 15) with assistance by one tugboat the ship was contacted with fenders of pier No. 1 by aft part port side hull. Hull damage is 1 x 0.5 m. vertically above load line.

Ship stand in the floating dock No. PD-812 port of Klaipeda. During early morning of June 16, 2016 around 03:32 LT inflammation (fire) was noticed by ship's crew on watch in vicinity of the SB aft hopper alleyway tank 202. At that time welding/cutting works were performed by welders of the shipyard to hopper plating. One crew member provided extra fire extinguishers to yard's workers present to try to extinguish the fire. Fire was already too big to be extinguished with extinguishers (also lot of smoke noticed). Other crew member informed shipyard about fire and contacted the captain. Shipyard send fire extinguish car and extinguish crew also contacted the local emergency services.
Around 03:50 LT fire was contained and emergency services did final checks before they left.
Around 04:30 LT, crew did smal inspection at place of incident. Noticed a lot of smoke traces and presence of water in alleyway and tanks, also deformation (damage) on several places in ships structure noticed.

Location: Around 550 kilometres north of New Zealand
SummaryOfEvents:
Two men and a woman have been rescued from their battered yacht, Platino, around 550 kilometres north of New Zealand by the crew of the container ship Southern Lily.

A deckhand was lost from the 9.8m potter when he jumped into the sea in an attempt to cut free a rope that had fouled the boat’s propeller.The boat had been operating in the middle of the English Channel when the its propeller became fouled by a rope from its fishing gear. This caused the vessel to be anchored to the seabed and unable to manoeuvre. Efforts by the crew to clear the rope were unsuccessful and, after about 30 minutes, a deckhand decided to jump into the sea and try to cut the rope from the propeller. However, a strong tide swept him away from Our Sarah Jane and he was subsequently lost. During the attempt to rescue the deckhand, another member of the crew jumped into the sea, but quickly got into difficulty and had to be recovered back on board the boat.
The investigation identified that:
• The deckhand jumped into the water despite the vessel’s skipper instructing him not to do so; and the deckhand was possibly under the influence of drugs.
• Both crewmen almost certainly suffered from cold water shock.
•The attempted recovery of the deckhand from the water was impeded by the vessel being anchored by its fishing gear and because a lifebuoy attached to a buoyant lifeline was not readily available.
• The 2nd crewman’s entry into the water to assist the deckhand was well intentioned but the risks involved were not properly considered.
• Emergency drills could potentially have improved the response to the fouled propeller and also identified the shortcomings in the availability of the lifebuoys.
A recommendation has been made to the vessel’s owner aimed at ensuring that lifesaving equipment is readily available and improving the crew’s ability to deal effectively with emergency situations.

Between 7 and 9 June 2016, the two occupants of a motor cruiser died from carbon monoxide poisoning. The boat was moored on an inland waterway, and their bodies were found during the afternoon of 9 June in the boats forepeak cabin. The investigation identified that: The source of the carbon monoxide was exhaust fumes from the boats eight-cylinder petrol engine, which contained high levels of the gas even when the engine was idling. The engine was probably being run to charge the boats 12v batteries and the occupants did not recognise the danger from the exhaust fumes. The carbon monoxide from the wet exhaust at the stern of the boat spread under the canvas canopy on the aft deck and then into the forepeak cabin, where it quickly reached lethal concentrations. The boats habitable spaces were not adequately ventilated; the forepeak cabins deck hatch and port holes were shut. The boats occupants were not alerted to the danger because a carbon monoxide alarm was not fitted.

SummaryOfEvents: The fishing vessel PATRICIA II was on a return voyage to Sandhamn in Blekinge after having been at sea for about two days. PATRICIA's crew consisted of the master who fished alone. Weather conditions were good, with a north easterly wind direction and a steady wind speed in average of 7-9 m/s and moderate seas. During the voyage, the master did not need to pay much attention to wind and waves and the fishing boat was operated with autopilot. The fishing boat's three cargo hatches and engine room door were closed. Shortly after half past two in the afternoon, PATRICIA was about 1-1.5 hours (about 8.5M) from the port of Sandhamn. The master was in the wheelhouse and was only wearing work pants and a thin shirt. The wheelhouse door was in an open position. For some reason, due to a sound or a feeling according to the master, he looked astern and saw that most of the working deck was covered by sea water. The sea water, or the wave as the master experienced it, came from the starboard side. The master turned off the autopilot and reduced the speed. He did not take any other immediate action, but noted that there was an abnormal amount of water on deck in the view of the prevailing sea condition. After two or three minutes according to the master, PATRICIA started to heel over more to the starboard side. It became clear to the master that the situation was no longer under control and the boat was about to capsize. At the same time as the master stepped out of the wheelhouse, PATRICIA started to capsize all the way to starboard. The master did not have time to send any emergency message via VHF radio or phone. The master ended up in the water along the fishing boats port side as the boat now was floating upside down. The master managed to reach a loose floating ball fender and a plywood board that he managed to get tied up on. The master's partner was planning to meet the fishing boat at the port. When PATRICIA did not arrive at the stated time and attempt to contact the fishing boat did not succeed, she felt that something serious must have happened and she alerted the Joint Rescue Co-ordination Center, JRCC. The Maritime Administration's SAR helicopter started and flew towards PATRICIA's last known position. After a while, the helicopter saw a larger piece of wreck like a floating table top. When the helicopter approached this object, it was discovered that a person was tied on the board. The master was winched up to the helicopter and was conscious, but heavily chilled. The helicopter flew to Karlskrona where an ambulance met for further transport of the master to hospital. The investigation has not been able to determine the exact cause of accident. The Accident Investigation Authority estimates that the most likely cause of loss of stability, is a combination of successive water ingress into the hull of the fishing boat together with a limited amount of seawater on the work deck at the end of the event. After that, the fishing boat completely lost its stability and capsized. Contributing to the event is the lack of ship inspection system for ship in the current size, and therefore there is no control that the boat complies with current safety and stability regulations.
Consequences1: Pollution,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

On 13 May 2016 a small passenger ferry, with 15 passengers and three crew on board, ran into a pier while it was attempting to berth. The ferry became wedged under a pier and its wheelhouse was demolished, but there were no serious injuries and there was no pollution. The MAIB investigation identified that: The confined nature of the ferrys normal berth at the pier afforded little space in which to safely abort an approach in the event of a mechanical malfunction. The collision resulted from a loss of control of the ferrys water jet propulsion. The cause of the loss of propulsion control could not be identified but it was almost certainly due to a mechanical failure within the systems hydraulic circuit. The potential for similar mechanical failures to occur in the future cannot be discounted. Injuries to passengers were avoided by them being seated and warned of the impending impact. Following the accident, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA) withdrew the ferry's passenger safety certificate and the ferry was sold by its operator. In view of the action taken, no recommendations were made.

Preliminary information indicated that FV Lu Rong Yu 58398 was towing a fishing net with another boat, FV Lu Rong Yu 58397,off Xiangshan coast in the East China Sea.  At about 0341, while making an alteration of course to starboard to prevent a collision, it was alleged that Catalina snagged the fishing gear, which resulted in Lu Rong Yu 58398 capsizing in position 29 32.23 N  123 35.88 E, with the loss of all persons on board.  At the time, the weather was overcast and the visibility was poor.  Both the second mate and able seaman who were on duty on the bridge, reported that they were unaware of any physical contact with the vessel.
During the course of the safety investigation, the MSIU was informed by the Maritime Safety Administration of the People s Republic of China (MSA) that paint samples on the underwater portion of Catalina matched with the chemical characteristics of the paint on Lu Rong Yu 58398. Moreover, the safety investigation found that the bridge on Catalina was not properly manned to match the exigencies of navigation in restricted visibility and the observation of traffic by radar was inadequate.

SummaryOfEvents:
At 17:23 LT on 13th April 2016, while Tug and Tow “BAK 20 and barge BAK 21” were transiting Al Qulay’ah channel with pilot onboard, one fishing boat “Mawah” came between the Tug and Tow to free a tangled fishing net to the towing bridle (Figure 1). Once Mawah came underneath the towing cable it capsized and three fishermen fell overboard. Two of them managed to swim toward another  fishing boat nearby while one was missing. The duty pilot contacted Bahrain Port Control (BPC) to ask for Coast Guard assistance. One Coast Guard patrol boat arrived at the scene and recovered the missing fisherman. The pilot continued his way to buoy No.1 and disembarked at 18:00. Coast Guard reported to BPC that the fisherman has passed away.
The investigation revealed  that  the fishermen underestimated the risk associated with tug and barge maneuvering and did not pay attention to the warning signals sounded by the tug.

No injuries or pollution were reported. The ship sustained damage to the hull. Initial refloating attempts with assistance from the tug 'Dabhol' were unsuccessful. All crew were rescued. Reef corals were damaged by the stranding. The wreck was abandoned in situ. The owners were ordered to remove it.

On April 11, 2016, the Normandy Ro-Ro passenger ferry departed Ouistreham at 3:28 pm (UTC + 1) bound for Portsmouth. At 17:08, a violent flash occurs in the main switchboard located at the engine control room, causing serious burns to a technician from the company "Schneider Electric" who worked nearby. A second electric flash occurs, in a very short time, causing a start of fire followed by a blackout. The fire is quickly controlled by the crew. The technician, as well as a crew member intoxicated by the fumes released by the fire are evacuated by helicopter to Lille University Hospital at 19:20. Normandy loses its propulsion at 5:28 pm and remains adrift. The propulsion is restored at 19:29 and the ship docked at Cherbourg at 23:48

The ship caught fire in a hydraulic unit on forward deck whilst undergoing completion works at the FSG shipyard, Flensburg, Germany at 1900 hours lt. The blaze was extinguished 1 hour later with assistance from local fire services. No injuries were reported. The extent of the damage was unknown. Inspection and repairs were effected.

Early on 9 April 2016, the fishing vessel Louisa foundered, with the loss of three lives, while anchored close to the shore in Mingulay Bay in the Outer Hebrides.
The skipper and crew, who had been working long hours before anchoring late the previous evening, had woken suddenly as the vessel was sinking rapidly by the bow. They were able to escape to the aft deck, activate the emergency position indicating radio beacon (EPIRB), and to don lifejackets. However, they were unable to inflate the liferaft as they abandoned the vessel.
At 0232, an alert from Louisa’s EPIRB was detected by a geostationary search and rescue satellite and forwarded through the Cospas-Sarsat system to the United Kingdom Mission Control Centre (UKMCC). The UKMCC relayed the alert to HM Coastguard, but confusion over terminology resulted in delays before search and rescue units were sent to the scene.
When Barra lifeboat arrived in Mingulay Bay, the crew were able to assist one crewman, who had swum to the shore and climbed onto rocks. They located the uninflated liferaft and beside it found the skipper and one crewman unresponsive and face down in the water, despite wearing approved abandonment lifejackets. The other crewman had attempted to swim to the shore and was found, also face down and unresponsive, still wearing his lifejacket, close to the beach. The skipper’s body was lost as the lifeboat crew attempted to recover him and remains missing.

Shortly before noon, a crew member on NORDIC STANI discovered that the Chief Engineer, who had gone out on deck for duties, was missing. The vessel was searched and shortly thereafter turned to the opposite heading. A SAR-operation was performed, but the Chief Engineer was not found. The cause of the Chief Engineer s disappearance has not been possible to establish with certainty. A possible cause, however, is that he has fallen overboard as he attempted to move between a cross-bay and the deck and then died. A fall from a ladder that he must have used could have been made possible by the fact that an arrangement to prevent fall did not exist. A contributing factor may have been that the vessel at the same time turned to port, causing it to heel somewhat to starboard.

The ship caught fire in the engine room whilst undergoing repairs at New Amsterdam. The blaze started in the main electrical panel and spread to other areas of the ship. It was extinguished by the crew. No injuries were reported. The ship sustained significant damage and was beyond economical repair. It had to be sold for breaking up.

On 5 April 2016, the wooden fishing vessel Fredwood (BA 338) berthed alongside its usual drying berth in the port of Maryport in Cumbria, UK. 
However, as the tide went out and the vessel grounded, it listed to port, away from the quay wall, and came to rest on a sonar tube protruding from the bottom of the boat. 
This caused damage to the hull planking in the vicinity, which in turn then allowed water ingress as the tide came in on the morning of 6 April 2016. 
As a result of this, the vessel flooded and sank alongside the berth. 
All of the crew were rescued by the local fire brigade and suffered no injury. Fredwood was pulled upright at high water whilst completely flooded, and pumped dry later that day as the tide receded. The vessel was subsequently towed to a slipway on a high tide the next day, where she was lifted out of the water. 
Following an insurance survey, the vessel was declared a constructive total loss.

Location: SOUTH PACIFIC 150 MILES NE OF EFATE ISLAND

SOLASStatus: ESPERANZA: SOLAS, SEHID OMER HALISDEMIR (EX:EZINE): SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo vessel named ESPERANZA flagged Cook Islands and the Ro-Ro ferry named SEHID OMER HALISDEMIR (EX NAME:EZINE) flagged Turkey collided at a distance of 0,56 miles from the Çanakkale Ferry Pier-Pier at 00:17 in 03.04.2016. Material damage occurred in both vessels as a result of the collision, however, no fatality, serious injury or environmental pollution happened.

The vessel had been sailing downwind. The wind increased in strength and backed and the crew started to reduce sail by reefing the mainsail, the skipper taking the wheel. Once the mainsail had been reefed, with some difficut;y the skipper tacked and a crew member went below to summon help to take down the headsails. On returning to the cockpit, she became involved assisting another crew member without first clipping on her tether. The combination of the yacht's motion and a wave breaking over the deck caused her to lose her footing and she fell down to the starboard guardrail. Another wave washed her overboard. An MOB recovery operation began immediately. It took several attempts to rescue the crew member, during which time she lost consciousness. All efforts to revive her on board were unsuccessful.

SUMMARY On the afternoon of March 19, 2016, the solid bulk cargo merchant vessel (M/V) ISA, 35.000 tons of deadweight and Cypriot flag, bound to the mouth of the port of Tarragona, while the pleasure craft (P/C) CHARLIE IV, sailed from Cambrils (Tarragona) to the port of Port Ginesta (Barcelona), following the route of the 3rd race San Patricio. Around 14:07 UTC, the two vessels collided at a point about 4 miles from the SSW green light at the port entrance. As a result, the sailboat suffered the mast breakage in three pieces, which fell on the deck and into the water. There was also a small waterway in the coastal area. The merchant suffered no apparent damage. After recovering the mast and controlling the water entry by its own means, the P/C CHARLIE IV was towed by the salvage vessel SALVAMAR DIPHDA to the port of Cambrils for repair. There was no personal injury among the occupants of the sailboat and the crew of the merchant ship. CONCLUSIONS The P/C CHARLIE IV ended up being boarded by the M/V ISA for failing to maintain adequate surveillance of its route in the period of time since its last beating leg off Cape Salou and the collision, as required by COLREG Rule 5. The skipper, sitting on the wheel on the windward side of the boat during this time, never saw the merchant approaching on a collision course, because he was being concealed by his own sail, and he did not regularly monitor this dead zone of vision. When he saw the merchant appear behind his sails, collision was inevitable. The M/V ISA ended up colliding with the P/C CHARLIE IV for not detecting its presence or not respecting the rules of passage of the COLREG. If it is true that the sailboat was detected early, the M/V ISA should have maneuvered to guarantee it a safe passage through its bow, it had multiple options to achieve this in the situation in which they were approaching. Something as simple as contacting the skipper via VHF and agreeing to slightly correct the course a few degrees to port to always lick the wake of the sailboat and allow it to pass through its bow in a safe crossing of both ships. However, the absence of communication and warning attempts and the continuity of course and speed after the impact, allow us to conclude that they did not exercise effective surveillance in the bridge of the M/V ISA that could have detected the supposed changes in course of the vessel as required by COLREG Regulation 5. No Safety Recommendations have been produced but some generic "lessons on Safety" have been added at the end of the Report.

Location: Approximately 150 to 200 meters  from the shoreline of Paradise Beach Resort, Samal Island, Davao de
InitialEvent: anchor dragging that leads to damage to submarine cable
SummaryOfEvents:
On or about 0915H of 17 March 2016, M/V Ecuador, a 998.72 GT container carrier ship departed Pier 2, Sasa Wharf, Davao for General Santos City. While transiting in the vicinity of Pakiputan Strait, the ship allegedly encountered failure on her main generator which prompted her to automatically discontinue her propulsion. Due to the prevailing sea current in the area, the ship started to drift towards the shoreline of Paradise Beach Resort in Samal Island, Davao Del Norte. In order to prevent the ship from running aground, the Master ordered the starboard anchor to be dropped at approximately 3 shackles. Apparently, the anchor allegedly hit an underwater cable.

The damaged underwater cable was identified to be a submarine electrical cable owned by the Davao del Norte Electric Cooperative (DANECO) supplying power from the mainland to Island City Garden of Samal (IGACOS). According to the Coast Guard Davao Station Report (CGSDVO-0316-025) dated 17 March 2016,  M/V Ecuador dropped her starboard anchor in order to prevent the ship from grounding due to the prevailing sea current. Tug assistance from nearby M/tug Schedar operated by Harbor Star Inc. was utilized to assist and prevent M/V Ecuador from drifting towards the shoreline.

By 0955H, the ship’s propulsion  was restored and she started to heave up her anchor. The crew of M/V Ecuador noticed that an underwater cable had been snarled in the fluke of her anchor and the crew tried to detach it with the assistance of the tugboat. After several attempts, the crew successfully disengaged the cable allowing the ship to proceed to her next port of call at around 1000H.On or about 1335H of 17 March 2016, representatives from the DANECO reported the incident to Coast Guard Sub-Station (CGSS) Sasa that the incident has caused power outages in IGACOS.

Location: WEST COAST OF KASHIWAJIMA, OTSUKI, HATA, KOCHI PREFECTURE
SummaryOfEvents: The ship was stranded on rocks, took water and subsequently sank on the west coast of Kashiwajima, Otsuki, Hata, Kochi prefecture in heavy weather. An oil slick of 700 x 50 meters was reported on 15/03/16 and an oil boom laid by the local coast guard to contain the spill. All 5 crew were evacuated safely. The remaining heavy oil is to be removed prior to salvage operations.

Location: Off Shimen in New Tapei, northern Taiwan, China
SummaryOfEvents:
Early in the morning (around 1:00 AM) on 10 March 2016, the container ship TS Taipei, carrying 610 containers, nine of them reported to contain dangerous goods, ran aground over a rocky shallow on the northernmost point of Taiwan, china, in severe weather and sea conditions following its loss of propulsion due to an engine failure. The ship had approximately 400MT of IFO 380, 46MT of MDO and 1500 litres of lube oil on board. 
All the 21 crew members were safely rescued by Coast Guard ships and NASC helicopters within the accident date.
On 24 March, the ship was split in two due to heavy weather conditions, releasing an unconfirmed quantity of oil, which subsequently stranded on the shoreline adjacent to the casualty.
Eight containers carrying toxic materials on the fore-side deck were removed by a crane ship from the ship on 1 April 2016, and all remaining containers on the deck were removed from the deck by 5 April 2016.
On the shoreline, clean-up operations were well under way, managed by the local contractor Sea green and overseen by the authorities. More than 250 people were mobilized to rapidly remove the oil from the shoreline.
As of 5 April 2016, it is estimated that up to 20 kilometres of shoreline have been impacted, with varying degrees of contamination
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: Alongside town quay at Dartmouth, UK
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship developed a list to starboard, took on water and capsized whilst moored alongside town quay at Dartmouth early in the morning on 10/03/16 in heavy weather and low spring tide.
Local authorities including fire services attended the scene. All 5 crew were safely evacuated. No injuries were reported. Five litres of oil leaked into the sea and an oil boom was laid to contain pollution. Salvage contract awarded to Multraship. Work barge Seadevil arrived at Dartmouth on 31/03/16 to assist with refloating operations. Refloated on 02/04/16. Towed to Brixham, UK for repairs.

The ship sustained damage to the bulbous bow with minor oil spill. The Seychelles coast guard deployed oil booms at the scene. All valves were shut to prevent an ammonia leak. On March 5, 2016 the fishing vessel SANTO NIO left the port of SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE to fishing tuna. Thorought the day and part of the night they were preparing the bait to start the morning following the tuna fishing. On March 6, 2016 at 18:49 hours after the end of the fishing day, they sailed to the area of Los Cristianos to anchor looking for more favorable weather and maritime conditions. Around 22:09 hours, with the skipper was alone on the bridge, the vessel aground near the Punta Rasca lighthouse. As a result of the impact there were damage to the keel and crack in one of the fuel tanks on the starboards side. The fishing vessel tried to get away by its own means producing damage to the gearbox. They were towed to Playa San Juan for another fishing vessel, where some divers made a repair of the tank to stop the small fuel leak.

The vessel was bound for Hong Kong for bunkers.  In preparation for the bunkering operations, and in order to avoid mixing the new parcel of bunkers with the one already on board, the chief engineer instructed the second engineer to transfer all the fuel oil from port heavy fuel oil (HFO) storage tank to starboard HFO storage tank.  The fuel oil transfer was carried out successfully as requested by the chief engineer. However, towards the end of the transfer, the second engineer noticed that the low level alarm fitted on port HFO storage tank did not activate.

Suspecting a fault in the low level alarm switch, the second engineer instructed the third engineer to overhaul the alarm low level alarm switch on port side HFO storage tank in order to identify and rectify the fault. At about 1710, immediately after dismantling the low level alarm float switch, fuel oil escaped almost instantaneously from the opening. It was immediately evident that the tank from where the low level alarm switch had been removed contained a significant volume of fuel oil and there was enough static pressure for the leaking fuel oil to reach the main engine exhaust manifold.

The third engineer tried to mount the fuel oil low level alarm back to the tank in an attempt to stop the fuel oil leak. However, in view of the heavy flow and the high temperature of the fuel oil, he was unsuccessful. Soon after, the fuel oil coming in contact with the main engine s exhaust manifold auto ignited.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On 5 March 2016 at 06:55 hours, the Liberian registered ALMI VOYAGER sustained damage as a result of adverse weather while the vessel was underway from Kizomba, Angola and bound for Philadelphia, USA. At approximately 14:00 hours on the day before, the weather had begun to deteriorate. The steering was shifted to manual and bridge watch status was elevated to BCII. By night time, winds had reached hurricane force. At 06:00 the following morning, the vessel Master informed the head office of damage found at the starboard quarter of the vessel. By 06:30, the Master and Chief Officer proceeded to the starboard side of the accommodation superstructure to assess the damage. The wind and waves were coming from a direction that was abeam of the starboard side. The starboard lifeboat sustained damage; two life rafts were lost; the embarkation ladder of the starboard lifeboat was detached and some minor scratches were found on the hull of the vessel.

The ship caught fire following an explosion in a pump room whilst anchored off Nishtun, Yemen late on 05/03/16. The extent of damage is unknown. Two crew died and 3 crew sustained injuries. All 3 injured crew were evacuated to a hospital in Salalah, Oman for medical attention. The ship subsequently arrived at a shipyard in UAE for repairs.

TNI had deployed two patrol boats to conduct the rescue when the incident was first reported. Several of the passengers had already been rescued by fishing boats when the rescue team arrived. Preliminary investigations showed the incident was caused by a leak that occurred just as the ferry had departed Gilimanuk, Bali, towards the Ketapang Port in Banyuwangi, East Java.

SummaryOfEvents:
Early this morning at 4:30, MRCC in Nouméa received a distress signal sent from an EPIRB located in Vanuatu waters between Efate and Erromango Islands.
A military plane, Guardian, took off from Toutouta, New Caledonia. The plane located the capsized cargo ship of 46 metres in length, LC Mahalia. The crew of 13 were on board a life-raft and were contacted by the plane.

Location: ANCHORED IN THE BIGHT OF BANGKOK 1 MILE OFF THE BREAKWATER AT LAEM CHABANG
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took on water, developed a list to port, capsized and sank whilst anchored in the bight of Bangkok 1 mile off the breakwater at Laem Chabang, Thailand late pm on 27/02/16.
No injuries were reported. A 500 x 30 metre oil slick was reported. Oil booms were laid and dispersant sprayed to contain the spill. Thai authorities despatched a team to monitor any possible environmental damage. The owner had abandoned the vessel at anchorage for more than a year and had been requested to remove the ship from the scene before the incident. Local fishermen reported the list 4 days before the capsizing of the vessel.

The body of a man  was discovered after he fell overboard a vessel moored in Tauranga Port, according to New Zealand Police Department.
The incident occurred in the morning hours of February 27, while the man, working as a deckhand aboard the bulk carrier MV Mount Hikurangi, was helping to secure a cargo of logs.
Local police and coast guard personnel launched a search and rescue mission to find the crew member.  The body of the man was recovered from the bottom of the harbour at around noon the same day.

Location: Approximately 300 meters from Salome Port Gumaca, Quezon
InitialEvent: swamping and death of three (3) passengers
SummaryOfEvents:
On or about 1530H of 26 February 2016, Mbca “Lady Aimee”,a 28.29 GT wooden-hulled passenger motorbanca left Gumaca, Quezon to Quezon, Quezon. Allegedly, due to increment weather and rough sea condition, the Boat Captain decided to return the passenger motorbanca to Salome Port for shelter after being struck by two (2) successive breaking waves on her port bow. Whilst maneuvering towards the direction of Gumaca, Quezon, Mbca “Lady Aimee” was being battered by swells and violent wavesat approximately 300 meters off the shoreline of Salome Port, Gumaca, Quezon.

Seawater entered the forepeak compartment of the ship, prompting her forward to inundate and take on more water on deck. Mbca “Lady Aimee” was weather-beaten by strong waves causing panic among her passengers. The crew instructed the passenger to move towards the stern in order to compensate the motorbanca’s trim. However, the action prompted the motorbanca to lean more on her aft and the accumulation of seawater on her astern compartments incited the vessel to trim by the stern and take on more water on her engine room compartment. MINERVA’s Master ordered the O/S to the bridge to signal (using the ALDIS lamp) to NETTUNO. NETTUNO subsequently altered course 10 degrees starboard of MINERVA. On 22 February 2016 the vessel anchored at Lumut Roads, Malaysia. As the vessel would stay for long time at the anchorage, it was decided to collect water from the Air Condition’s drains.  The 2/E and the Oiler (victim) were ordered by the C/E to find the position of the Air Condition’s Drain Pipe so that they can connect it to a tank for collection of the drain water. They were wearing Safety Harness, a Safety Helmet and Overall.     
In order to find the Air Condition’s Drain Pipe, they climbed up a ladder next to the Engine Control Room (ECR) and then through a platform on top of an Air Duct, to reach the pipes’ network. The Oiler stayed on the top of the Air Duct and the 2/E went to the Air Condition Room. The 2/E knocked the pipes and the Oiler distinguished the right pipe (Air Condition’s Drain Pipe) from the noise made by the knocks. 
 At about 09:30 hours the work was completed and the 2/E ordered the Oiler to go down to the Engine Room Platform where the ECR is situated.  He proceeded down first.  At about 09:35 hours, the Electrician on his way to the ECR found the Oiler with his  head and shoulders hanging out of a Void Space’s vertical Manhole. He was bleeding from the mouth and was calling for help.   
The Electrician called immediately the 2/E and the C/E. The 2/E pulled the Oiler by the shoulders out of the Void Space and placed him on the Engine Room Platform. The C/E informed the Officer of the Watch (OOW) on the Navigation Bridge, who informed the Master. All crew was informed about the accident via public announcement. The 2/O carried the stretcher and the First Aid Box.  They placed the Oiler on the stretcher and transferred him into the ECR. Then, he was transferred from the ECR to the ship’s Hospital. The 2/O checked his pressure and administered to him Oxygen.      
 At 10:30 hours, the pulse of the injured Oiler could not be measured and the blood pressure was zero. Personnel from the Malaysian Maritime Administration and from the Malaysian Marine Police boarded. The Oiler was transferred ashore by boat around 18:00 hours.  Post mortem examination results: Causes that led to death: “Polytrauma Secondary Fall From Height”.

A 10.8m ocean rowing boat was on passage in the North Atlantic Ocean, between the Canary Islands and Barbados. Shortly after 2300, a rower was swept overboard by a large wave and he soon became separated from the boat.
The seven rowers remaining on board were unable to stop the boat, and they eventually lost sight of him.
The following day, French and Portuguese fixed wing aircraft and a cargo ship searched the area, but the missing rower was not found. The rowing boat's crew were recovered on board the cargo ship leaving the abandoned rowing boat to drift. The cargo ship arrived in Brazil, 6 days later.
The investigation identified that:
●● The rower had not been adequately tethered to the boat.
●● The boat’s low gunnels1 afforded little protection against a person falling overboard.
●● The rower became separated from the boat because the leash he was wearing
detached from his ankle and the boat could not be stopped in the prevailing conditions.
●● The rower’s likelihood of being found was reduced because he was not wearing a lifejacket or a personal locator beacon.
●● The boat was operating on a commercial basis but it was not certified as a commercial vessel.
Ocean rowing is a niche sport that has grown in popularity, but the boats used and their operation, is largely unregulated. They are also vulnerable when on ocean passage, where assistance is rarely immediately at hand. Although elements of best practice for the sport have been established over the years, these have not yet been formalised or applied consistently.
Recommendations have been made to improve the governance of UK registered ocean rowing boats and ensure minimum safety standards on board those that are commercially operated.
A recommendation made to the rowing boats operator is aimed at improving the safety of its boats on ocean crossings in the future.

On 22 January 2016 at about 0225 hours LT (UTC+8 hour), the Panamanian registered vessel MV “Castle” and another Panamanian registered vessel MV “Dumun” collided in the Singapore Strait, in approximate postion Lat 01° 14.6’N; Long 103° 57.01’E. Both vessels had taken pilots to transit the Eastern anchorages in the Singapore Strait to their repective destinations. At the time of collision the pilots of both vessels had already disembarked from the vessels earlier. 

The vessel MV ‘Castle’, a bulk carrier, was leaving the Singapore Eastern anchorage heading Eastebound for a voyage to Miri, Malaysia, with a pilot on board after some repairs to the deck equipment and taking bunkers.  

Whereas, the vessel MV ‘Dumun’, also a bulk carrier was leaving the Singapore Eastern Special Purposes ‘A’ anchorage after taking bunker fuel oil and transitting with a pilot towards the Singapore Strait Westbound Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) on her intended voyage for Djen Djen a port in Algeria, North Africa.

At the time of the collision at 0225 hours LT on 22 January 2016, the weather was fine and the visibility was good and clear with light breeze. The speed of the MV Castle was about 7.8 knots. The other vessel MV Dumun’s speed was about 8.5 knots. On board both the two vessels, the radars were in operation and in working order

The two vessels were approaching each other on a crossing situation. The MV Dumun was on the port side of the MV Castle. At 0210 hours when the pilot disembarked from the MV Castle, the MV Dumun was about 2 nautical miles on the portside of MV Castle. MV Dumun still had a pilot on board. At 0224 hours, MV Dumun dropped off the pilot. By this time the two vessels were 0.2 nautical mile apart. It appeared that collision was imminent. Both vessels were communicating with each other on VHF Channel 14 on what avoiding action to take to avert collision. However, it was too late for the two vessels to avert collision.

At about 0225 hours, both vessels coliided. The MV Castle sustained damage to the port of her bulbous bow. On the MV Dumun, she sustained damage to the shell plating on the starboard quarter in way of No 1 settling tank and service tanks. There was some bunker fuel oil leaked into the sea. The vessel was not taking in water. No one on board was injured. The vessel proceeded to anchor at an anchorage near Batam, Indonesia.

A 16m wooden potter sank close to a gas pipeline off Shetland. The vessel’s sinking resulted from a flood in the engine room that had started sometime between 0900 and 1000. The skipper and crewman abandoned into a liferaft shortly after they became aware of the ingress of water and were rescued by a nearby fishing vessel. No efforts were made to stem the flood and the vessel foundered approximately 4 hours after it was abandoned. There were no injuries and no pollution. The pipeline’s owner later arranged for sandbags to be placed on the seabed between it and the wreck to prevent damage to the pipeline.
The cause of the engine room flood is unknown but it was probably caused by a failure within a seawater system or sea valve. The investigation identified that:
•
The engine room’s bilge alarms sounded in the wheelhouse and were not heard by the skipper and the crew who were working on the deck. Consequently, the engine room had been flooding for up to 1 hour before the crew were alerted.
•
The rate of the flooding would have been slowed by the operation of the electric bilge pump and possibly by stopping the main engine.
•
The effectiveness of the crew’s response to the flood was probably reduced because they did not routinely conduct emergency drills.
•
The prompt abandonment and notification to the coastguard and vessels in the area reduced the risk to the lives of the crew.
This accident indicates that relevant guidance and the lessons from similar accidents were not being sufficiently heeded. In the accident, the wheelhouse was left unattended for a prolonged period and the crew were not practised in reacting to a flood on board. In addition, they did not wear personal flotation devices while working on deck and did not don lifejackets when abandoning the vessel.
Initially, the two crew of the vessel were unaware of the flooding as they were both working on deck when the engine compartment bilge alarm activated. The alarm was in the wheelhouse which had been left unattended for over an hour. 
Once the crew discovered the flood in the engine compartment, the alarm was raised and without further investigation in to the cause of the flooding they abandoned ship in a well executed manner. The fishing vessel finally sank after four and a half hours. 
The crewmen were safely recovered from their life raft by another fishing vessel that responded to the distress call. There were no injuries and no significant pollution.

On January 21st, 2016, the bulk carrier MV GARNET was about 6 hours from its discharging Port of Keelung, Taiwan, China. She was sailing along the Northern coast of Taiwan, China, towards Keelung. Her distance from the nearest land was about 5 nautical miles. The weather condition at that time was passing showers with moderate sea condition and long moderate swell. MV GARNET was rolling moderately. At about 0105 hours (Local Taiwan Time) in estimated position Latitude 25˚ 21’ North, Longitude 121˚25’ East, the Chief Officer, Mr. Arif Rachmad Hidayat, who was the watch keeping Officer at that time was found missing. The duty AB (Mr Ammad Helmi) who was on lookout duty together with the chief Officer at that time could not locate the Chief Officer after he was last seen walking out of the bridge to the port side bridge wing, 10 minutes ago. As the vessel navigation needed attention and the Chief Officer could not be located, AB Ammad Helmi, called the Master immediately. The Master came to the bridge and took over the watch. After ensuring that the vessel was safely on track, he mustered his crew to carry out a thorough search onboard for the missing Chief Officer. The Search Parties could not locate the Chief Officer onboard. Fearing that a Man Over Board (MOB) had occurred, the Master went on a reciprocate course and continue to Search the sea area. Ship’s spotlights were directed to the sea level in an attempt to locate the Man Over Board. MOB procedures as per company safety management procedures were carried out. After searching for over 3 hours, in the last known area where the Chief Officer was last seen, the missing Chief Officer was not located.

The Master contacted the company’s DPA and the Coastguard. At the same time, the ship broadcasted an urgency message seeking vessels around the vicinity to keep sharp look out for a man overboard. The Master back tracked the ship’s route and carried out a search of the sea area but did not find any sign of the missing Chief Officer. 

At the time of the incident, the vessel was fully loaded with bulk sand and gravel (20514 M/T – see Annex 10) from Xiamen, China, bound for Keelung, Taiwan, China. The owner and management of the ship are based in Keelung, Taiwan, China.

Location: IN THE SOUTH ATLANTIC OCEAN 10 MILES SW OF CAPE POINT
SummaryOfEvents:
Partially sank after collision with MV 'Sunrise Jade' in the South Atlantic Ocean 10 miles SW of Cape Point, South Africa on 19/01/16 in dense fog.
Two NSRI rescue boats, nearby MV 'Portos' and FVs 'Freesia', 'Armano', 'Cape Frio', 'Flame Thorn' and 'Dan Tago' proceeded to the scene. All 14 crew abandoned ship to a liferaft and were subsequently rescued by 'Freesia' and taken to Cape Town, South Africa. No injuries were reported. The half-submerged wreck is still afloat.

A fire aboard the boat PeeJay broke out as it was returning from White Island to the town of Whakatane.  All 53 passengers and seven crew members were forced overboard to escape the fire and smoke.

One passenger and one crew member were taken to a local hospital after suffering from minor injuries and smoke inhalation.

The boat was about 1 kilometre (0.6 miles) from shore when authorities were first notified of the incident, and they called on nearby boats to assist.  The PeeJay crew then sent a mayday to say they were abandoning ship.  Four other private vessels and the New Zealand Coastguard were able to get to the scene quickly and rescue everybody. The PeeJay later sank.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 09 December 2015, MV Galaxy arrived in Malta under tow on a single, ballast, unmanned voyage from Piraeus, Greece to the Shipyard. Repairs commenced soon after, with the vessel afloat. On 08 January 2016, she was transferred to graving dock no. 4 for underwater hull inspections and repairs. She was subsequently re-floated and pulled out of the dry-dock on the morning of 18 January 2016 at around 0900 to continue repairs afloat alongside Boat House Wharf.
During the berthing operation, after the move out of the dry-dock, a roller from the pedestal fairlead at the aft mooring station became detached and flew off over the shipside and overboard. In its trajectory, the roller head hit the Shipyard’s Assistant Repair Manager who was consequently fatally injured.
The Marine Safety Investigation Unit (MSIU) conducted a safety investigation into the occurrence. The safety investigation revealed that the immediate cause of the accident was the failure of the two 10 mm bolts holding the roller-keep in place, which sheared off under the tension from the mooring ropes.

Location: IN THE ANCHORAGE OFF COLON, PANAMA
SummaryOfEvents: Sank after collision with an unknown ship in the anchorage off Colon, Panama on 18/01/16. All crew were rescued. The ship had been laid up awaiting towing to a demolition facility. Sustained damage to port side of hull in the collision, took on water and developed a 45 degree list to port prior to sinking on 22/01/16. Local authorities monitored the incident scene for possible pollution. The wreck is lying on its side in 16 metres of water and has been marked with buoys as a navigational hazard.

At dusk on January 16, 2016, Saturday, the fishing vessel (F/V) CANALECHEVARRIA was fishing approximately 37 miles north of San Sebasti n when a fire was declared in the engine room. After a first unsuccessful attempt to turn it off, the skipper sent a Mayday on channel 16 of VHF warning of his situation and returned with the crew to try to extinguish the fire. Meanwhile, SAR Company SASEMAR deployed its means of aid while two other F/V, which were in the vicinity, came to the distress call of the F/V CANALECHEVARRIA.The fire was finally extinguished by the crew, so the skipper requested the F/V to be towed to safe port.The fishing vessel was towed by the rescue vessel (R/V) MARIA DE MAEZTU to the port of Bermeo (Vizcaya), where it arrived at 09:00 hours on January 17th.CONCLUSIONSThe most likely cause of the fire was a short circuit caused by the contact of the containment wire mesh of a hydraulic hose with the terminal or cable body connected to the positive terminal of the ship's dynamo. The hose was previously weakened by rubbing against a ledge or metal edge, having lost material from its protective cover at the point of friction and causing the double steel mesh to be exposed. The relatively small size of the area in which the hose ruptured leads one to think that the point of friction had to be a metallic edge or similar, close to the breaking point, like the flat terminal of the positive terminal of the dynamo.The short circuit, by melting the metal of the double mesh, caused rupture of the inner layers of the hose and made possible the leakage of the hydraulic oil under pressure that contained. This, together with the high temperatures produced by the short circuit, much higher than the flash point of the oil, caused it to burst into fire.The decision of the skipper to disconnect the hydraulic machinery was determinant for the fire to run out and to be extinguished.The underlying causes or factors contributing to the accident were:1) The installation of the hose that caused the accident was done improperly. The person who performed the hose replacement should have done so in accordance with industry recommendations for these facilities. In this case, the installer did not consider two problems:a. The existence of free parts of the hose that, with the vibration of the ship, rub against parts of other equipment and pipes, andb. Installation of the hose was done too close to electrical conduits.2) Result of the above, it is evident the lack in the operation of the ship of an effective maintenance and inspection system.

SOLASStatus: MINERVA PISCES: Unknown/unspecified, Zhe Pu Yu 42234: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Minerva Pisces sailed from Sitra, Bahrain on 25 December 2015, bound for Daesan in the Republic of Korea. The vessel had a mean draft of 12.50 m (even keel).
On 13 January 2016, at about 0035 and two nautical miles from Minerva Pisces, the OOW observed a number of fishing boats forming a large group, moving at a speed of eight knots, on course of 074° and crossing from port to starboard. The boats were reportedly not engaged in fishing.
The OOW stated that he flashed the Aldis Lamp in the direction of the boats. The OOW reported that one boat crossed the vessel’s bow at a very close range.
He quickly changed to hand steering and ordered the AB to put the helm to port. The OOW stated that he then moved to the bridge wing and saw the fishing boat passing clear on the starboard side.
The MSIU has no compelling evidence to confirm that physical contact was made between the two vessels. However, the echo of one of the fishing boat was lost on the radar whilst crossing Minerva Pisces bow.

On the afternoon of 13 January 2016, the roll-on roll-off ship Spirit of Tasmania II was loading passengers and vehicles in Melbourne. At 1750, strong wind gusts blew the ship off the wharf and all but one of the ship’s mooring lines (on the bow) parted. As it broke away, the stern swung around until the ship was 90 degrees to the wharf and parallel to the nearby public beach, in danger of grounding. Action was taken to arrest the swing and the ship was returned to the wharf without touching bottom.

Wharf cargo and vehicle loading infrastructure was seriously damaged. The ship suffered minor bow damage. No one was injured.

The ship was stranded on the beach in Pierpont bay at Ventura, CA, USA in heavy weather. Local emergency services attended the scene and rescued all 3 crew. No injuries or pollution were reported. Sustained damage to the hull. Fuel and other pollutants were removed. Salvage costs exceeded the vessels value and demolition in situ commenced on 14/01/16.

Location: ATLANTIC OCEAN 50 MILES NW OF LA CORUNA
SummaryOfEvents: The ship sustained a crack in the hull, took on water, developed a list to starboard and sank in the Atlantic Ocean 50 miles NW of La Coruna, Spain on 10/01/16 in heavy weather. Rescue boat 'Guardamar Concepcion Arenal' and other nearby ships proceeded to the scene. All 11 crew abandoned ship to a liferaft and were subsequently rescued by Sasemar EC-225 helicopter 'Helimer 401' and taken to La Coruna. Two were hospitalised for medical attention. The Sasemar CN-235 aircraft flew over the area the following morning to check for debris and pollution.

Location: The Sea Wall off Sakata, Yamagata Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: The vessel grounded on the Sea Wall and the part of the vessel below the bridge submerged.

InitialEvent: Fatal accident- Fell into cargo tank
SummaryOfEvents: On 10th. January 2016, at about 0200 LT, while vessel approaching Kingston, Jamaica Pilot station from Pascagoula, Alabama, USA, 2nd.Officer instructed 3rd.Officer  to pick up the pilot via VHF radio at position Lat 17-59.5N Long 076-47.6 W. When pilot boat approached, 3rd. Officer was unable to contact again. Master activated the search team. The team search accommodation, main deck. At 0248 LT, search team found the Third Officer body at the bottom of the opened manhole COT 6 Portside. The manhole cover kept opened to free gases for class intermediate survey.

SUMMARY Early in the night of 10 January 2016, located 48 miles to the NNW of A Corua, a water ingress was declared in the engine room of the F/V NOVO JUNDIA. The vessel was with 11 crew on board. The vessel had sailed towards the port of A Corua from Great Sole fishing area. The Chief Engineer witnessed the water ingress and, alone, immediately initiated all efforts to contain and reduce the flooding, with no result. The crew sent distress calls and abandoned the vessel on the liferafts.At 21:06 UTC on the same night, SASEMAR's main MRCC received communications from several international MRCCs, which had received a distress call by medium wave radiotelephony from a ship near the Spanish coast. Minutes later, at 21:12 hours the MRCC Finisterre managed to establish communication with the F/V through the Maritime Communications Centre A Corua, being informed that the vessel had a waterway and was sinking.SASEMAR immediately mobilized ships in the area while deploying of its own means, with the result that the survivors were rescued by a SASEMAR helicopter without personal misfortune. The trawler sank in position 44 09,9' N 008 40,8' W, to 400 m deep. CONCLUSIONS In view of the evidence found and the information available, it must be concluded that: 1) According to the eyewitness account of the facts, the water leak was caused by the breakage of the main sea chest valve, in its union with the box of the port sea chest. 2) There could have been an area on the top plate of the sea chest housing or on the sea valve flange, whose material was weakened or corroded by cracks and/or rust.3) Thickness measurements did not detect weakening on the upper surface of the housing; therefore, it is assumed that the problem must have been found in the soldering of the flange to the sea chest or in the connection of the flange to the valve. However, due to the random nature of the ultrasonic measurement technique, it cannot be ruled out either that there was a region of the upper surface of the sea intake, connected to the flange, which was in poor condition and whose state would have gone unnoticed in the inspections carried out. 4) These measurements, moreover, only guarantee that the thickness of the plates is maintained, and do not give information on the state of the structure in edges, weld seams or assemblies such as a flange, so it is necessary to carry out an effective visual inspection on these elements, which could not be carried out by the layer of cement deposited on top of the sea intake.5) The upper part of the sea opening was covered with cement. Interpreting the declarations of the first mechanic, this layer also included the flange and the immediately connected part of the valve:"the water flowed between the cement and the valve". However, based on the evidence available, it is concluded that this layer necessarily had to be less than 100 mm thick. 6) As a consequence of the previous point, any problem of corrosion or weakening that could occur in the upper plate of the sea intake, in the welds, and in the structures that would settle on it would be hidden from the visual inspection of the crew and the successive statutory recognitions. 7) The chief engineer took approximately 85 minutes to sound the alarm, when the situation was practically lost. It would have been better to have alerted the rest of the crew first so that the first mechanic would have been able to get help and the rest of the crew would have been able to take more time to call for help and leave the ship.8) While the both skippers did not follow the procedures established in the GMDSS, it is considered that the combination of the nerves inherent in the situation together with the use of inappropriate equipment, such as survival suits with mittens, meant that the skippers misinterpreted what was happening: that with mittens they were unable to operate the 5 seconds required to trigger a distress alert by DSC on any of the equipment. By mistakenly thinking that the equipment was not working they asked for help through an obsolete system as it was calling for the frequency of 2182 kHz in Medium Wave.9) The sinking probably took place when the flooding progressed towards the fishing park and, from here, presumably by some opening made when installing the ice machine towards the hold.
Consequences1: Pollution,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: A bulk carrier identified as the CHINA STAR 107 that went missing for four days sank in the East China Sea. The ship, with five crew on board was en route from Shanghai to Fuzhou where it was expected to arrive on January 9, with a cargo of steel and wood. The bulk carrier is reported to have gone missing some 3 nautical miles off Fuzhou North Island on January 8. It is planned now for the divers to enter the wreck, within search and rescue efforts for potential crew members who remain unaccounted for. A helicopter has been dispatched to the scene to look for potential survivors and local fishermen have also been notified to be on the lookout.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The German-flagged coaster EVERT PRAHM transited the Kiel Canal westbound on 8 January 2016 during her voyage from Liepaja in Latvia to Husum in Germany. The bridge was manned by the chief officer and a cadet. A canal pilot was also on the bridge. A 2-3 Bft south-easterly wind which was slowly turning to the south-west blew in the early hours of the morning. Inter alia, snow and black ice warnings had been issued for the Rendsburg-Eckernfrde area. There was snow and freezing rain during the night. Wind forces of 4-5 Bft with gusts of 6-7 Bft were measured at Rendsburg after 0600. The air temperature stood at about 3 C and there was light rain. The EVERT PRAHM approached the railway bridge at Rendsburg in darkness at 0635. Her speed over ground (SOG) was about 8.8 kts. The transporter bridge suspended below the railway bridge was on the northern bank of the Kiel Canal at the time. In addition to the operator, there was also a passenger on the transporter bridge. The EVERT PRAHM kept to the middle of the fairway and was just short of the railway bridge when the transporter bridge set off toward the southern bank. Despite the EVERT PRAHM executing a full astern manoeuvre combined with hard to port, it was not possible to prevent the collision. The transporter bridge struck amidships against the hatch, was briefly snagged, rotated, and then released again. It then struck the starboard wing before scraping over the wheelhouse, dragging the antenna, radar and stern mast with it in the process. The EVERT PRAHM sailed gently onto the southern embankment at canal kilometre 62.5. She freed herself unassisted by means of a stern manoeuvre. She then sailed into the Kreishafen of Rendsburg and made fast there at 0715. As a result of the accident the Kiel Canal and the railway bridge at Rendsburg were closed to maritime traffic and to rail traffic respectively. The transporter bridge was severely damaged due to the collision and partially torn out of the rail track. It was stuck over the middle of the Kiel Canal. The operator was seriously injured due to the collision. The only passenger on the transporter bridge was also injured. With the assistance of the canal ferry MEMEL, both people could be rescued from the transporter bridge and taken to hospital. The emergency responders managed to re-engage the transporter bridge and move it to the southern side of the canal by about midday.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
M.V. Ocean Prologue departed port of Colombo to Chittagong on 04.01.2016.While en route she ran aground on well charted Uheliya Reef in the coast of Sri Lanka.  No pollution,no injuries reported.
Her underwater area was inspected by divers in the presence of a class surveyor. Later she was re floated with the assistance of a tug on 06.01.2016
Consequences1: Ship remains fit to proceed,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Propeller fouled by nets, drifted onto rocks and then sank off Lofotodden, Moskenes, Norway in heavy weather.  All 5 crew were rescued by RONAF Sea King helicopter and taken to Bodo, Norway for medical checks. No serious injuries reported. NSSR rescue boat 'Det Norske Veritas' attended the scene but was unable to prevent the ship from drifting ashore in the severe weather conditions.
Vessel burned due to causes unknown. Vessel was a total loss.
